summary: Two years before the Civil War, Django (Jamie Foxx), a slave, finds himself accompanying an unorthodox German bounty hunter named Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz) on a mission to capture the vicious Brittle brothers. Their mission successful, Schultz frees Django, and together they hunt the South's most-wanted criminals. Their travels take them to the infamous plantation of shady Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio), where Django's long-lost wife (Kerry Washington) is still a slave.

Holy Cow! I'm not a fan of Tarantino, in general. But Jaime Fox, Samuel L. Jackson, and Christophe Waltz killed it in this movie. It is dark, bloody, and still maintains elements of humor, irony, sadness, and redemption. 

It IS a Tarantino movie; some people will be offended. There is blood, foul language, gratuitous violence, and more blood. It is also action-packed, humorous, and human. It is definitely not for everyone, but for me - this movie fills a niche in my movie experience that has been filled by nothing else.

Django Unchained is probaly my second favorite Tarentino movie after Inglourious Basterds. The script is so perfectly written, even if this movie seems a bit simple on the surface, which it is absolutely not. Django Unchained has some gorgeous cinematography and sound design, combine that with beautiful production design and costumes and you get a visually pleasing movie. Christoph Waltz, Jamie Foxx, Samuel L. Jackson and Leonardo Di Caprio are all academy nominated level good, they all have their own scenes to shine in. The thing that took me out of the movie sometimes, was the use of modern music, sometimes it worked, however most of the time it definitely didnt. The thing I probaly most like about Django Unchained, is it use of style. Tarentino is not afraid to heavily zoom in or use stylish blood, which makes the movie so much more interesting to look at.

It's bold.  It's brash.  It's stylish.  It's unmistakably Quentin Tarantino.  In Django Unchained, Django (Jamie Foxx) and King Schultz (Christoph Waltz) are bounty hunters with two goals ‚Äì kill as many wanted men as possible for the rewards offered and rescue Django's wife from the clutches of Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio), a ruthless plantation owner.  As you'd expect from Tarantino, it is beautifully shot, intelligently written with plenty of memorable dialogue, and is filled with interesting characters.  As you'd also expect from Tarantino, it's filled with ridiculous excesses.  Clocking in at almost three hours, the final thirty minutes is filled with absurd violence that detracts from everything that came before it.  It's probably fair to say that subtlety is not something you expect from the likes of Tarantino, but you certainly expect something more than silliness.

Django Unchained directed by Quentin Tarantino tells the story of black slave Django played by Jamie Fox who is set free years before the civil war by German Dentist  Dr. King Schultz played by Christoph Waltz joined together to catch criminals and eventually end up in Candyland, a plantation owned by Candie played by Leonardo Dicaprio in order to rescue Django's wife from slavery. This movie is wild as most of Tarantino's work and it clearly is a revenge story of a black slave getting back on the white slaveholders a topic he sort of addresses in Hateful Eight. Jamie Fox and Waltz are an incredible duo with great chemistry as they around killing people left and right, of course Waltz's presence is strong with his signature charisma. Leonardo Dicaprio dazzles as Candy a white sophisticated slave holder who plays good manors until he reveals the darker side of himself and is terryfing. This movie is fun even as it offends with the repeated use of the n word, and gory violence. Django is a likeable character and we cheer for him as he sets out on his journey. I cannot forget to mention the smaller but significant role of Sam Jackson as a slave serving Candie who's actually in support of slavery and racist himself and hates Django, a cringy role but one where Jackson delivers in a memorable performance. An academy award winning screenplay with great performances and great direction by Tarantino this might be one of my favorite tarantino films.

Django immediately caught my attention from the very first scene. From the cinematography to the slight comedic relief at times, I knew this film wasn't going to have the typical slave narrative we've been accustomed to. The film did a decent job at touching on the dynamic between white and Black people during the 1800's. The first scene between Django and Dr. Schultz, with Dr. Schultz buying Django from the slave owner, we see the beginning of what seems to be another "white savior" narrative. I was quickly mistaken when realizing that throughout the movie Dr. Schultz might've played the role as someone "saving" Django, but ultimately only served as a catalyst in Dango's journey to save his lover. The relationship between the two characters is mutual in that Dr. Schultz uses Django to find the Brittle Brothers and Django uses Dr. Schultz to find his way back to his love, Broomhilda. One character that stood out to me the most was Sheba. She's a Black woman in Mr. Candie's home. Unlike the other Black women/salves, she's bejeweled from head to toe, dressed in elaborately rich clothing, all while sipping  alcohol from the upstairs bar. Her name, Sheba, is a reference to the Queen of Sheba from the Old Testament in the Bible. Sheba means "is very rich" and stood out to me because it's also a reference to Ethiopian literature. Additionally, throughout the film we see the cinematography used when zooming into characters from a wide angle and quickly into a close shot, we also follow the character arc of Django who was once a slave, soon become a free man, and later save his love all while defying the odds of what it meant to be a Black man at the time.

My first time watching Django Unchained was last week. The movie deals with a lot of different issues such as slavery, gruesome violence, and race for example. When I first watched it, there were some scenes that I found to be disturbing. I find that Tarantino over-use of the n-word in his films, and not just this particular film, can come off as offensive for some. But within this particular film, because of the historical time-period the movie was set in, the use of the n-word was said on a daily basis. Reminds me that there are certain people that can't say the word in today's society.¬† Freedom here is a major theme. In my opinion, the theme of being a white savior was also present in the film. It is this false belief or implying that African-Americans need white people to "save them" or to "rescue them" in order for them to have a better life. In my opinion, the character Dr. King Schultz played that role a little bit when he freed Django. Towards the end of the movie, we see that Django has gained the knowledge and skills that were taught by Schultz once he died, to go rescue his wife and Django being able to live as a a man without Schultz. There are a few things I think the film does well on and what the film doesn't do so well. One strength of the film is that the cinematography was so captivating and every little detailed was seen. There was a scene where one of the slave owners was shot by Django and we see the slave owners blood splattered onto the white cotton. This movie reminded me of a slave getting revenge on their slave owners and taking back their freedom. One weakness I thought the film could have done better was the way Broomhilda's character was portrayed. She was more of a physical entity as we can see from her being abused and sexually assaulted. There were other woman character's that had a different role, but I do wonder if she wasn't Django's wife, would Broomhilda still have gone through what she went through? Overall, I would recommend to watch this movie to others.

Tarantino is the kind of director who can take on any genre in the world and make an award winning film out of it. Though a western film, Django isn't a cowboy hero, rather a free slave anti-hero. He's neither good nor bad, but is a steadfast individual who ends up learning a whole lot from the German bounty hunter who freed him. The only thing he wants back is his beloved wife, but ends up facing brutal violence, harsh negotiating, and formidable plantation owners. The fiery revenge in Django's attitude throughout the film gives the feeling that he might explode at any given second, yet he somehow fastens it to a leash. He is an attentive, patient, yet zealous man slowly making his way from the bottom to the top. The use of wide angle filming in this movie captures every bit of vivid landscape imaginable in 19th century Texas, giving the viewers a deeper appreciation for Tarantino's masterful filming in which he habitually displays. Really can't say much more than this. Just watch it now.

The honest review of Django Unchained

Django Unchained is a movie directed by Quentin Tarantino. tells the story of a slave by the name of Django, who is the protagonist in the American south who becomes meets a german dentist who is a bounty hunter by trade and goes on a crazy adventure to kill wanted men and through a turn of events try to find Django's true love. 
There are many things that make the film great. One of the things is how the director used old legends to foreshadow the events that eventually unfolded at the end of the film. This happens when the german dentist told Django the story of Broomhilda, which is a character in the most popular old German legend. 
Another thing that makes the movie amazing is the beautiful cinematography along with the music. It immerses the audience and makes them feel like they are part of the adventures of Django. The movie also has an interesting take on the social commentary as it highlights the issue of slavery. It does this not only by portraying the mistreatment of African Americans but also by showing that some slaves like being obedient to a master or "the white man" because it has been embedded in their minds that slavery is something that can not go away and is here to stay. This gives rise to an interesting argument about the character of Samuel L Jackson. It makes the audience question whether the character is mistreating Django because he has been washed by the system or is he just an evil character. 
	Finally, the film takes an interesting take on who the antagonist is. This is because unlike other films(such as Inglourious Basterds which is also directed by Tarantino) where the whole movie from the beginning to the end builds up to fight the antagonist, as this movie progresses, the antagonist changes, and Django finds himself fighting new enemies. Overall, I would give this film a 5 out of 5 stars.

Charming, charismatic, heroic. Not the words I thought I'd ever use to describe a movie with slavery, violence, gore, and nudity, but Quentin Tarantino has without a doubt made one of the best movies of the decade with Django Unchained. Jamie Foxx plays Django, a daring ex-slave, who teams up with a bounty hunter, Dr. King Schultz, played by Christopher Waltz, to rescue his enslaved wife. First off, I have to say that I have never seen Jamie Foxx this charismatic in any role prior or since, he hits every note of his character perfectly, Django is tough and gritty, rash but methodical, smart but inexperienced. And every aspect of that character shows in Foxx's flawless performance. Christopher Waltz, as well, is incredibly charming, and downright loveable as the lethal but principled German doctor/bounty hunter. Leonardo DiCaprio as the plantation owner Calvin Candie manages to perform his heart out in what should've been an Oscar nomination, I mean that whole bit about Frenology was hands down brilliant. The fact is, it is Tarantino's ability to not only write his characters with remarkable depth, but also give the actors the freedom to perform to their heart's content, that fleshes out and completes many facets of the film that would be otherwise empty. Tarantino can be, as usual, a bit overindulgent, there are a number of scenes not relevant to the plot that if deleted, would have ended about ~30-40 minutes earlier. However, I'd also argue that the extra runtime grants each actor more time to shine and by proxy make the overall film better. 
Speaking of indulgent, the classic Tarantino violence is just as prevalent in Django Unchained, revolver shots blow body parts off and launch people into the air with spectacular blood, smoke and sound. Yet the violence in this film is also more restrained, more conservative and less gratuitous than many of Tarantino's other movies, likely because he smartly sticks with the use of simple handheld revolvers and pistols for the most part. With Tarantino's signature R-rated style, some of the best performances by the best actors of the decade, and a classic (yet new) Western plot that does not hold back even a drop of blood and sweat, Django Unchained is a downright brilliant film, and one of Tarantino's absolute best. It 100% deserves to be seen again, and again, and again.

One of my all-time favourite western films, "Django Unchained" is an absolute thrilling and enjoyable film to watch that keeps you hooked from the incredible opening to the satisfying end. In terms of Tarantino films, this is definitely one of his more memorable films, having a classic western feel while also having a completely fresh feeling. Foxx and Waltz carry this film, though DiCaprio, Johnson, and L. Jackson are also absolutely fantastic in their roles. I feel like the film is unnecessarily over-the-top in terms of its violence, depicting an unbelievably high amount of blood and gore that just does not seem needed. I can also see some people getting offended by the insanely high amounts of racial slurs against African Americans said in this film, though it does have a positive message about equality in it. In the end, I really loved "Django Unchained" because of how much fun the entire film is, having a surprisingly large amount of very dark humor that keeps the film from being too serious.

To me a Django Unchained seemed like an already amazing movie, combining the Western with Quentin Tarantino's film-making, and I was right. The movie is classic of Tarantino, violent and edging onto humorous. The trouble with this one is that it had to carefully cover the theme with slavery which it did fairly well. The movie followed Django, a slave, killing various white slave owners as a bounty hunter by the side of a German outlaw to eventually reunite with his wife, still trapped as a slave. What stands out in this movie was the characters as most of them were unique and well-acted. Christopher Waltz was funny and drove the movie for me and the villain of Leonardo DiCaprio was similarly amusing. The action throughout the movie was in classic Tarantino fashion, over the top to the extent of it being laughable, exactly what I was expecting and it fitted fairly well into the revisionist frame. I feel what the movie occasionally struggled with was the development of its lead, Django played by Jamie Foxx. Foxx is a great actor but I feel like his character wasn't fleshed out at all, and his portrayal in the movie was more as a simple man looking for revenge. This wouldn't be so much of an issue if this was so directly addressed by the direction but it became a hinderance when compared with the other characters, instead serving as some kind of stark contrast of characters which arguably could have worked well. Overall, I think this movie fits well into the revisionist Western sub-genre and serves as a great addition to Tarantino's collection of great movies. If you're a fan of Westerns you should probably watch this, and if you're a fan of Tarantino, even more so.

Not an incendiary masterpiece, but a masterpiece none-the-less. First and foremost, the attention to detail in the setting and the masterful dialogue carry the film. Every line in the film packs a punch because it has a realistic quality to it. Films with the honesty such as that seen in Django need to be made even if a splash of over-the-top gore is prevalent along with some absurdism. When you watch Django, you feel for the two protagonists while hating the antagonists. The line is strictly drawn in this film between good and bad which makes for a hard watch at times. Overall, Django Unchained is an undisputed masterpiece from the collection of Quentin Tarantino.

The Fastest Gun in the South: Django Unchained 

Quentin Tarantino's impressive directing power in Django Unchained brings you two hours of light humor, intense violence and emotional drama. While Django Unchained is profane, provocative and raunchy, it also demonstrates an ability to unravel America's legacy of slavery through a suspenseful plot. 

What makes Django Unchained so great is its ability to combine various different film genres into one movie. It fits revisionist western, adventure, romance, dark comedy and drama genres. Tarantino's use of dark comedy and violence in Django Unchained and his other movies resembles Stanley Kubrick's style, particularly in A Clockwork Orange. Both Tarantino and Kubrick's movies could fit countless genres as they capture the archetype of conflict between good and evil. 

The cinematography is excellent, and the film does a strong job of capturing the slaves' perspectives. The first harrowing moments of the film show slaves walking all day with sweat dripping all over their faces and limping with huge cuts on their backs. Then the film takes off with a bloody moment 7 minutes in (a Tarantino classic). Right away, the audience is shocked by close-up shots of the inhumane conditions Django and the other slaves had to endure. 

Both main characters in Django Unchained want something: Dr. Schultz, a bounty hunter, wants the financial reward of killing outlaws, and Django just wants to rescue his wife from slavery. The film's social commentary aims to answer this question: What do humans need to be happy? One can see this theme through the journeys of the characters. Calvin Candie (played by Leonardo DiCaprio) gains false happiness through evil means such as exploiting other people, while Django seeks the true happiness of love.

Dr. Schultz foreshadows the plot when he explains an ancient German fairytale to Django. The story is about a German princess who is sent off to stay on the top of a mountain and is guarded by a dragon. A knight eventually kills the dragon and saves her. Django presents a similar story, but when presented through the harsh realities of slavery, the story takes on more powerful levels of meaning. Overall, Django Unchained is a true cinematic masterpiece and I give it an A+.

Django: Unchained is by far the best movie I have ever seen. Django is a 2012 Western film directed by the legend, Quentin Tarintino. The cast consists of Jamie Foxx, Christopher Waltz Leonardo Dicaprio, Samuel L Jackson, and other amazing actors and is set in the mid 1800s. Django, a slave is rescued one day by Doctor Schultz from the horrors of slavery to assist him in a bounty hunting mission. After Django helps Doctor Schultz, Doctor Schultz promises to reunite young Django with his wife who was sold to another slave owner along time ago. What follows is more than an hour of amazing screenplay. First off, the acting is incredibly solid and some of the best I have ever seen. Waltz and Jamie are like butter and bread in this film and are incredible and watching them on the screen together is like magic. The music, the acting and incredible journey make this one of Tarintinos best films ever. Dare I say one of the best movies EVER. Period. Highly recommended.

(Jamie Fox, Christoph Waltz, Leonardo DiCaprio, Kerry Washington, Walton Goggins, James Remar, Don Johnson, Bruce Dern & Samuel L. Jackson)

Set in the Wild West in Texas in 1858, a former dentist turned bounty hunter named Schultz stumbles upon the Speck Brothers who are in transit moving slaves they own. Schultz gets to talking with a slave named Django inquiring if he's heard of the Brittle brothers, upon affirmation of such information Schultz proceeds to purchase Django if he helps him locate and take care of the brothers than he would grant Django his freedom along with a horse and $75. Schultz then takes Django under his wing training him the ways of the bounty hunter and he becomes his deputy. After successfully tracking and taking out the Brittle Brothers and many other targets over the winter Django tells Schultz his story of how he and his wife attempted to escape their former owner and then were sold separately, and how he would like to use that reward to purchase his wife back. They discover the location of a Mississippi plantation where Broomhilda, his wife , was sold. They learn the ruthless Calvin Candie Von Shaft is the new owner and they now know that a scheme needs to be plotted to successfully purchase Broomhilda without raising suspicion that she was the target all along. 

For a nearly three hour movie it certainly doesn't feel that way as the film is so action packed that it'll keep you on your toes the entire duration of the film. A beautifully produced piece of film that stacks up with every other great Tarantino film, it just fits the mold so perfectly. Well developed characters and a unique story like none other. So much originality has been missing in westerns i feel like this one fueled the next decade of great westerns that have been released. This long list of actors in this film is quite extraordinary as there was even more great actors i could have listed. The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal and I'll admit i listen to this frequently it just fit the film perfect. The dialog was written so nicely creating some iconic scenes. Anyone who truly loves film can not get enough of this Tarantino masterpiece.
Great action, amazing soundtrack, relevant message, and the acting chops of Foxx, Waltz, and DeCaprio.  Django Unchained is incredible.

Django Unchained is a very interesting movie to watch. Quentin Tarantino keeps audiences on their toes by including scenes and tones of drastic contrast. The cinematography varies wildly, in classic Tarantino fashion, from gruesomely gory closeups to comedic wide shots of group encounters.

Django's character arcs in a way that reflects a classic hero on a quest. In the beginning, Django is picked from a group of seemingly ordinary slaves (notably, the lowest ranking members of society). By the end, he is central in the plot to dethrone the white men with the most power. Django becomes a bold grim reaper character symbolizing raw, unforgiving power in the fight of Good vs. Evil. The complex relationship established between Django, Schultz, and Candie creates immense tension and draws interest from the audience. The depiction of Good vs. Evil reflects the brutality and societal structure of the time.

What's perhaps most satisfying about this film is its resolution, which requires sacrifice to settle the conflict and allows Django to get what he wants. Tarantino is masterful at integrating gory threads that foreshadow each other. For example, Schultz' use of the spring action revolver to kill a central antagonist appears multiple times. Each time, I was filled with satisfying shock and joy, as I knew another climactic moment was ensuing.

I am not usually the biggest fan of Tarantino movies in all honesty. They're usually just a little bit OTT for my liking. I've tried to like the Kill Bills films, Inglorious Bastards and The Hateful Eight but I just don't love them. Granted I didn't mind Pulp Fiction but I'm not a massive lover of it. This film though for me is different. It does have a few moments where I know it's one of his films and a few moments that could really be cut to bring down the runtime down but, I was too invested in the movie and outcome to care. The violence is as always ramped up to 100 in this movie but it really works, with Django one of the best gunslingers around. It makes for some stunning shoot outs and action sequences. I'm not usually a lover of too much blood. I just feel it's unnecessary but in this movie it just works under the context of everything seen on screen. Another thing that I loved in this film is the music. The opening Django theme is so damn catchy and the blend throughout of western songs and hip- hop just really worked for me. There's not many directors that would blend those two genres of music together and make it work so massive kudos to Tarantino for pulling that off and helping inspire a killer soundtrack. 

This movie is more current now than it has been in the 8 years it's been out. The oppression and enslavement of black people is ingrained into almost all countries histories. To see how horrendously these people were treated is horrendous. It is highlighted by the ridiculous amount of times the 'N' word is used throughout. To see Django become a free man and rise up against these people who oppressed him and mistreated the woman he loves is a great thing to witness. Dr. King Schultz is the only white character in this movie with any conscience to how the slaves are treated. That really brings us in with our two lead characters and makes us root for them more. 

The cast though assembled for this movie is amazing. Jamie Foxx is outstanding in the lead role and just oozes charisma and cool. The "I like the way you die boy" line for me is iconic and it just wouldn't sound as good coming from anyone else but Foxx. Waltz though steals the show his character Schultz is so likeable and is the rare good guy in the film. He doesn't have to help Django but he does and goes out of his way to help him reunite with his wife. Leonardo DiCaprio as always amazes. It's not often we get to see him in the lead villain role but this is that rare film where he plays it. He can play the villain just as well as the hero and his characters depravity is really brought to life by his performance. Finally Samuel L. Jackson is unrecognisable from his cool and usually calm self. He's snivelly and a pure weasel as DiCaprio's head slave. Having four of the best actors around really helps bring this brilliant film to life. If you're fans of any of those actors then this film  is an absolute must see!

Quentin Tarantino is perhaps the most talented director of our generation and his skill of putting a fictitious twist on memorable moments in history can be seen throughout his most entertaining movie, Django Unchained. Django Unchained simply put is a Quentin Tarantino classic. The slave era, inspired story follows the journey of a recently freed slave, turned bounty hunter, searching for his long-lost wife while having to face racist obstacles at every turn. Emotions such as sadness, anger, and relief are felt as an audience member and even some laughs are to be had throughout the film. 

Topics such as racial inequality, love, death, and overcoming the odds are consistent themes seen throughout the movie. Tarantino even puts his own spin on the racial inequality theme by having the right-hand man to the owner of a plantation as a white supremist African American. 

Django Unchained proves itself to appeal to those with a strong stomach and mind considering the amount of violence and profanity used, but regardless Tarantino accurately depicts events that took place during the 1800's. So, make sure to grab your favorite snack because you are in for a rollercoaster of a movie.

Django Unchained Pros: Phenomenal Acting Superb Directing Outstanding Writing Excellent Cinematography Magnificent Editing Brilliant Pacing Sublime Storytelling The soundtrack choices are well-thought out Fantastic Production Values (Sets, Costumes, Makeup, etc.) Great Sound Design Cons: None A+ (10/10)

Its not bad, just feels kinda meh. overall it was really good!

Django (Jamie Foxx) is freed from slavery and hired by a dentist/bounty hunter Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz) to assassinate murderers and other slave owners who usurped the black man in the past. On their way, Django must make a visit to Mississippi to meet plantation owner Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio) and rescue his wife Broomhilda (Kerry Washington) and get his revenge. If that doesn't sound familiar, replace an ex-slave with a distraught bride, a bounty hunter with a Japanese swordsmith and trainer, the slave owners with the pack of assassins, and a wife with a five-year-old daughter. Also like Kill Bill, Django Unchained uses a cartoonish amount of violence, although the latter film uses bullet squibs hidden in blood packs over blood hoses and prosthetic scalps. Both use flashbacks in different color filters to symbolize torment of the main character. Finally, both star Samuel L. Jackson, Michael Parks, Laura Cayouette, and Zoe Bell, the stunt coordinator for Uma Thurman in Kill Bill. However, Django is reduced to the simple "damsel in distress saved by a heroic warrior" story, unlike the other film which is a test of marriage and child custody. Plus, 2012 film has comedic elements like the Pythonesque banter from the Ku Klux Klan and some amusing one liners from the cast. Lastly, Broomhilda appears as in Django's vision throughout his quest, whether in the cotton field, beside a tree, or in a hot spring. Even though Django has some powerful imagery and glorious usage of Tarantino's "showmanship", Kill Bill is more memorable because of its  complexity and depth. (4 Blood-Stained Boutonnieres out of 5)

I'm not much for Westerns. But when Quentin Tarantino is in the director's chair, I think we'll be alright. First off, this movie is really funny. All the witty dialogue, the shoot-outs, and the characters make this movie very entertaining. And I have to give props to everyone's acting. Jaime Fox is so awesome as Django. The way he talks, looks at people, and shoots a gun. But there's the person he learned from, Dr. Schultz played by Christoph Waltz, whom is also amazing in almost everything he does (he needs a good director, too). Then there's Leonardo DiCaprio and Sam Jackson as pretty much the villains. Both of them are such asses, but they do it so well. Jackson plays the head honcho of all the slaves and he *is* creepy, and DiCaprio plays the owner of the slaves. These are the kind of characters that you hate and love at the same time. And of course, there's the violence. It's bloody, it feels real, and doesn't mess around. I also appreciate that it's all practical, because CG usually sucks since it's cheaper. If you like Tarantino movies but haven't seen this one yet, you'll probably enjoy it a lot

Django Unchained has all of the Tarantino trademarks. There are recurring cast members, natural dialogue, drawn-out suspense, an amazing soundtrack, and a satisfying climax of bloody violence. The only thing missing is a scene involving feet.

The film is also justice porn at its finest. Django, a former slave, seeks revenge on the slavers who contributed to his (and his brethren's) condition. Tarantino gives us this simple plot and lets his characters run loose.

Speaking about characters, what an AMAZING cast. Everyone including Jamie Foxx, Christoph Waltz, Leonardo DiCaprio, Kerry Washington, Samuel L Jackson, Jonah Hill (a pleasant surprise), and many others deserve every reward and praise they get for this movie. The head of cinematography, Robert Richardson, and the entire sound team (Harry Cohen, Tony Lamberti, Branden Spencer, Dror Mohar, Wylie Stateman, Michael Minkler, and Michael Wilhoit) deserve special praise as well.

I would give Django Unchained, directed and cast by Quentin Tarantino a ‚Öò overall. I thoroughly enjoyed the Cinematography and old western feeling of the movie. The cast was also beautifully cut, my recurring favorite is of course Christoph Waltz portraying Dr. King Schultz and Leonardo DiCaprio, this time playing a completely villainous role as Calvin Candie. Django was also a blast to watch, the plot was very simple to follow requiring little effort to really pay attention to, lined with the outrageous and crude nature of the film kept me entertained through it's run time. The overuse of the N-word is its greatest downfall, and really plagues the movie from being seen by a wider audience in reality. If Tarantino would've limited its use or perhaps not used the word at all, maybe it would be portrayed in a different light. I think that Django Unchained could've been used to empower black people because at the core of the movie it's a slave revenge and justice serving movie. I think Jamie Foxx does a great job breaking the shackles, quiet literally, and making the audience feel great striking back at vile and cruel slave owners by delivering their own type of justice.

This movie is definitely a classic. It's better than The Hateful Eight and definitely more quick-paced. It was fun seeing a freed slave take revenge on other abusive farmers/plantation owners. "Django Unchained" is another incendiary masterpiece from the audacious auteur. Besides being Tarantino's highest-grossing film (reeling in $162,805,434 domestically), "Django" is possibly the most daring of his career. In his Oscar-winning screenplay that uses the n-word 110 times, Tarantino creates a modern blend of spaghetti and blaxploitation Western that tactfully finds humor in a KKK scene. Tarantino's ability to get the most out of actors is also on full display, from DiCaprio's utterly villainous depiction of Calvin Candie, the charming but cruel owner of the Candyland Plantation, to another Oscar-winning performance from Christoph Waltz as Dr. King Schultz, the veteran bounty hunter who masquerades in a traveling-dentist wagon.

Truly one of my favourite movies of all time. When people think about QT they straight away go to Pulp Fiction, but there is something that stays with me in this movie. Django, directed by Quentin Tarantino, is the success story of a slave given a chance at redemption when given his freedom and an opportunity to train in bounty hunting with a sympathetic German mentor figure Dr. King Schultz. Django's position as a freeman bounty hunter sets him up to overcome the overtly racist old western society which suppresses him as he is protected by law to kill any individuals which a bounty is placed on. Even though Tarantino gives Djangos character this safety net, he does an phenomenal job at keeping the audience in the times by using subtle instances of slavery in the background of scenes as well as hitting the audience with very difficult imagery to keep us grounded. And yet it is these appalling difficult to watch slavery scenes that has us route for Django's ultimate success against this oppressive system. When we are presented with one of Django's gruesome flashbacks, it justifies the violent actions Django takes as a bounty hunter as he usually was forced to suffer much worse treatment than he made his targets undergo. For example, when Django goes with Dr. Schultz to the first plantation why was it important that he whips the white plantation worker before killing him? Well for one we saw the flashback before this where Django's wife was brutally whipped by the same man and second it is the first instance where Django seems to feel a true sense of justice and righteousness in his bounty hunting occupation. 
	Overall I appreciated this film and believe that Tarantino was able to find a beautiful line balancing this dark and difficult subject matter with a lighter blend of comedy. It isn't easy to handle sensitive topics of racism such as the pre-Civil War American slavery era and the Holocaust in WWII, yet Tarantino finds a way to address these issues through fictional stories like Django and Inglorious Bastards which allow him to create unique plotlines and characters that sparks more engaging conversation regarding the subject matter as a result of the unusual circumstances we witness the subject matter in. I think bringing important ideas to light in an original fashions makes people think more critically about the film and therefore have more to talk about afterwards. Great film, would recommend if you have 2 and a half hours to burn.

Django Unchained ‚Äì The Boogeyman
This movie is on my all-time favorite list. Quintin Tarantino does a great job developing the story and the characters in a way that is organic and engaging. The dichotomy of who Django is and who he pretends to be can be seen as the boogeyman in the film. They discuss this fact in the movie about how there was nothing lower than a black slaver. However, I believe that the archetype is likely referring to the owner of Candyland, Calvin Candy. Comparatively, Django is only the fa√ßade of evil being a black slaver and his character is developed through Dr. King Shultz in an attempt to free his wife Hilda. So, we can argue that Django is perceived by others as the boogeyman but it's doing what is good for mankind. Unlike Django, Calvin is a creature of his environment that remains loyal to the ideology of slavery. The film arcs in a firefight at Candyland leading to the death of Dr. King Shultz.
Another possible argument for the Boogeyman in Django Unchained is Stephen. Being a slave himself, one would think Stephen would understand the plight of Django. This is not the case, however, as Stephen is the causer of the conflict at Candyland. In Calvin's absence, Stephen becomes the man who runs Candyland. He reprimands the slaves that try to run away, as in Hilda's case, this makes his role in the slave community a little more egregious. When speaking specifically of how the boogeyman is portrayed in Django Unchained, it is more obvious that the fear created by Calvin Candy is far greater than the fear created by Stephen. The notoriety of Candyland alone is enough to create fear for slaves. Stephen is just another aspect of the hell that Calvin Candy created.

Django: The Spaghetti Western Slave Film--

Django Unchained is violent, ruthless, and brilliant. The 2012 film is directed by Quentin Tarantino. The movie is set two years prior to the Civil War and follows the protagonist, Django, on his quest to free his wife Broomhilda from southern slave owners. Django befriends Dr. King Schultz, a German dentist turned bounty hunter, who grants Django his freedom and enters into a partnership agreement with him. The pair spend the Winter wrangling up the wanted outlaws of the South and amassing a fortune. Django and Dr. Schultz end their journey on the Candyland plantation in Greenville, Mississippi that belongs to Monsieur Calvin Candie. Here, Django and Dr. Schultz try to purchase the freedom of Broomhilda while undercover for a different business proposition, and all chaos ensues. 

Tarantino attacks the cruelty of slavery in this film. Southern barbarity is one facet of this film that appears to be historically accurate. Tarantino's use of graphic violence reminds viewers of the disturbing reality of our nation's history; a history that is often rewritten in textbook pages and generally unspoken of. Django Unchained is a reminder of the horrors of slavery in our country that occurred not too long ago. 

This film is not for the faint-of-heart or weak-stomached. Blood is one of the most prominent threads presented throughout the film. The overt, outrageous, and excessive depiction of blood in this film further emphasizes the barbaric cruelty of slavery. Torture, whip lashings, fighting, broken bones, cruel punishments, and a man being torn apart by dogs all make this film hard to watch. However, the graphic imagery is a reminder of the reality of our nation's history. The graphic violence makes viewers want to look away and turn their cheek, much like many people did to slavery. 

While tackling the brutality and immorality of slavery, the film also gives us a black protagonist to root for. Django is a badass cowboy who is quicker with his pistol than any other man. Tarantino draws upon the "spaghetti Western" film genre for inspiration. This film has saloon shoot-outs, pistol shooting, and bareback horse riding. This movie also has multiple allusions to German culture, including the fairytale of Broomhilda. Django is a real life Siegfried who walks through hell-fire to save his lady from captivity and ultimately emerges triumphant. Viewers root for the success of Django, and praise the demise of the southern slave owners. Soundtrack and music are used effectively to build emotions in this film. Modern music is used to make Django look like a badass, despite being set in the 1860s.      

Although this film was hard for me to watch, I think it was well-done. This film left me feeling guilty to be a white person from the South. The film made me laugh, cheer, cry, and scream. I think it's important to tackle difficult subject matters in film. I give this film 5 out of 5 stars.

Quentin Tarantino does not stop surprising us with his amazing historical movies to which he adds his own twists. Ask anyone and they will tell you that Tarantino's dialogues and cinematography can be recognized out of thousands of movies. "Django Unchained" is not an exception. In this case, the producer decided to accurately show southern barbarity during slavery times. The movie explores a story of the former slave, Django (Jamie Foxx), who together with a German dentist, Dr. Schutlz (Christoph Waltz), takes on a journey to find famous slavers - Brittle Brothers. 
	Throughout the movie, Dr.Schultz plays an important father figure as he teaches Django not only necessary survival skills but also aids in the development of his complex character. One cannot be surprised by the character arc of Django as numerous foreshadowing elements are presented in the plot. In the beginning, the protagonist is shown as a broken character who mourns separation from his wife Broomhilda. However, as the plot progresses it becomes evident that Django is much tougher than the audience expected. With the time Django feels more confident in doing what he wants rather than what people expect from him even if it means going against slave traders. 
	The recurrent archetype in the movie is "The Boogie Man". Leonardo DiCaprio did an amazing job of playing Mr.Candy. Despite me knowing that he is a slave trader I could not bring myself to hate him. A powerful and smart man who knows how to play people so he will get what he wants at the end. Not many people know that while filming a dinner scene, DiCaprio smashed the glass and cut his hand in a real-life, however, he kept on acting (for that scene alone I think he should have been nominated for Oscar). Even though Mr.Candy is a charismatic man, many fear him because of his unpredictability, one second he can be smiling and another command dogs to kill one of his slaves. Apart from his fortune, his violence and unpredictability are the qualities that made him famous in the South. On the other hand, the second time I watched the movie I thought that Django can be also called a Boogie Man: a former slave, who turned into "a killer of white folk". His story was quick to spread and many people knew who he was even before they met him. For the first time, white criminals are scared of an empowered black man who could kill them without any further consequences. 
	"Django Unchained" is a definite must-watch for people who crave skin-crawling scenes and witty dialogues. Its plot twists and numerous side stories will make you stay in your seat until the end.

Too nonsensical, too long, too bloody, too non-consistent. Not enough depth or development, the movie seems to be just a vehicle to show off the cinematographic proficiency of the maker. Also, Jamie Foxx may be heralded as a good actor, but here his character is entirely too flat, while he is supposedly the central figure. For my taste, I see Foxx way too often play parts of an angry, rather simplistic black man, which I suspect he is not at all in real life. He is at risk of becoming a typecast, if he is not already. While especially in Django he had a chance of providing an example to other African Americans and all Africans indeed, of showing growth and development throughout the movie. Evidently, Django was not intended for that by Tarantino. Having the pleasure of knowing in my environment many admirable, socially active, highlevel African expats to whom I (a white university graduate in government employment) can only tip my hat, I find it a great pity that Django was filmed in such a flat typecast way for the main character. While you certainly cannot expect Django to become the US president at the end - though he would probably do better than Donald Trump (pun intended), some more development would have been nice. As it is, I find the movie more of an insult than a liberation or an appreciation to the African Americans. It makes me wonder why Foxx wanted to do the part. If you look, on the other hand, at Django just as an off-hand story of a former slave getting his revenge on slavetraders and plantation owners, the movie does the trick. Even then though, it did not keep me on the edge of my seat or even interested, unlike other Tarantino movies like Pulp Fiction, Reservoir dogs, or recently The Hateful Eight. 
I have to classify Django together with Inglourious Bastards as a less interesting and indeed exhausting sit with way too little serious storyline. Perhaps amusing for simpletons and at risk of insulting large portions of the population left and right. Not very good, Quentin.

Django: Unchained is set in the year 1858 where, Django (Jamie Foxx) is a slave who is being transported along with other slaves to another plantation. Then a man named Dr. King Schultz (Christopher Waltz), a bounty hunter and dentist, wants Django in order to find some outlaws. After hunting down the outlaws, Django and Dr. King develop a relationship. Django tells Dr. King about his wife that is a slave at Candieland that is owned by Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio). Steven (Samuel L Jackson) is a servant at Candieland on a mission to stop Django from fooling Calvin Candie. The series of events lead to a huge explosive ending that audiences love.
	There are many reasons why Django: Unchained is one of the best movies of the last 10 years. With an Oscar in 2013 for best writing/ original screenplay, Django: Unchained does not let audiences down with amazing plot/subplots, characterization, setting, cast, and cinematography. The plot is very intricate with many moving internal and external plots; Yet, Django: Unchained keeps it easy to understand and fun for the audience. The characters are well thought out, while consisting of their own internal plots throughout the movie. Django: Unchained makes it seem by the end of the movie that the audience personally has a relationship with the characters. This film is also heightened by the setting of the movie. Quinten Tarintino has a reputation for setting his movie long before the current age. Tarintino keeps his movies historically accurate not leaving one detail out of time or place. The cast of the movie is arguably one of the most important aspects of a great movie. With Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L Jackson, Jamie Foxx, and Christopher Waltz truly owning the screen and really capturing the audience's attention to every line. Finally, the cinematography (the art of making pictures) in this film is one of Quinten Tarintino' s best. This film should be on the bucket list of every movie lover ever.
	The plots/subplots and setting are the groundwork to make a great film. The groundwork for Django: Unchained holds the great movie up. In the first 10 minutes the audience is brought to the two main characters Django and Dr. King. Dr. King introduces himself to the guards (and the audience) telling his name and life story, also his horses name. This sets up a mini plot for the introduction of the film. After the miniature plot resolution, the main plot sets up. There are also many internal and external subplots that are in the storyline as well. Including Dr. King's desire to help Django vs. his want for wealth. Also, Django's lifestyle as a slave vs. his life as a freeman. Quintin Tarintino makes his movies laid out so that depending on the audience's thoughts, the movie changes. But that isn't the only thing that makes Django: Unchained amazing.
	Characterization and cast are the other layers that make great movies. With the amazing star-studded cast, Django Unchained really blows away the audience. If a movie has a great scrip and well thought out, very in-depth characters along with great actors that can portray the roles, it will be a great movie. Django Unchained is one of the greatest examples of great roles with great actors. There are so many layers in this film that build the relationship with the audience and the characters. Either if you like Django: Unchained or not, you cannot ignore the pure beauty of the characterization in this film. But there is one more basic category that makes a top-quality film.
	Finally, cinematography is a large aspect to the movie making process. The way that the camera angles can create emotion and add intensity to a film. There are many examples in this film including, when Django and Dr. King walk into the bar and the camera zooms in on to the bar owner. This can add to the emotion of the scene and the intensity of the characters reaction. This is the art that is lost in today's clich√© films. Also, the angles of some of the action scenes in this movie are out of this world.
	This film is completely saturated with the components needed for a truly great movie. With a 91% audience rating, audiences seem to agree. Some parts of the movie can be gory and violent, but the movie is well balanced in comedy, romance, and even some mystery. If you liked any other movie directed by Quintin Tarintino or are just an action movie junkie like me, then Django: Unchained is a movie for you. That's why Django: Unchained is the best movie in the last 10 years.

Quentin Tarantino is not my favorite filmmaker, as has been well documented, but in attempting to watch every Best Picture nominee ever I have found myself watching Pulp Fiction (1994), Inglourious Basterds (2009) and this film. Of the three this was my second favorite as Pulp Fiction left me cold and Inglourious Basterds felt funnier and fresher than this film. This is still a significantly flawed film and the moments that were meant to leave me exhilarated and titillated never quite connected but I at least understood some of what Tarantino was aiming for. For Tarantino acolytes this should fulfill their needs but it doesn't reveal any depths to him as a filmmaker or a writer that will entice those not already enticed by his brand of loving pastiche.

Slave Django Freeman, Jamie Foxx, is picked up by German dentist turned bounty hunter Dr. King Schultz, Christoph Waltz, who shoots his owners and offers him the chance to go into business with him. Freeman and Schultz set out to kill the Brittle brothers and Schultz offers to help Freeman find and purchase his wife Broomhilda von Shaft, Kerry Washington, after a bond develops between them. They track her to the plantation of Calvin Candie, Leonardo DiCaprio, a sadistic Francophile who enjoys watching ‚ÄòMandingos' fight to the death and uses African-American women as prostitutes. Candie discovers the scheme that Schultz and Freeman have concocted and after a prolonged confrontation Schultz kills Candie and ends up dying himself. It is then up to Freeman to survive being captured by the employees of a mining company and to return to Candie's plantation so that he can reconcile with his wife.

Many referred to this as a "love story" but the fact that it focuses almost entirely on the male character and the female character is represented mostly through other characters talking about her it is hard to invest in this romance. We are meant to see this film as being a sort of fairy tale as the star-crossed lovers are reunited at the end of the film and the villains are all cartoonish and evil but Tarantino's love for blood and guts prevents us from being charmed by any of the characters. Washington does little more in her role than flinch and wince as we are asked to delight in watching her be abused and attacked in a way that makes this film feel more like a cheap exploitation film than the high art it parades as. 

The performances could also be also be described as a tad overzealous as DiCaprio, in a rare villainous role, chews the scenery but manages to appear as though he is trying far too hard and leaves us disengaged. I imagine the effect was intended to be both hilarious and menacing but I wasn't amused by his thick Southern accent or the fact that he couldn't speak French and while it was utterly horrid watching men abuse one another I was not convinced that Candie was cold or terrifying enough to carry out these actions. Jackson appears to be impersonating a minstrel as he plays a character who is rather confusingly written and it is sad to see an actor of his talent wasted on a role like this. Dennis Christopher pops up in a supporting role which strangely reminded me of Breaking Away (1979), a very different film, a disconcerting distraction during a film of this sort. Tarantino can draw the worst out of actors, as seen with Brad Pitt in Inglourious Basterds (2009), but with the amount of talent he manages to attract I am always shocked by how stupefying and misjudged their performances can be.

If you have a taste for bloodshed several scenes in this film will satisfy your craving but for me I felt that they were needless and the violence did not excite me or add anything to the story. In terms of 2012 films I don't think this was one of the best and I would have preferred to have seen Moonrise Kingdom (2012) and The Hunt (2012) nominated for Best Picture. Obviously every body has their own personal preferences and Tarantino happens to go against my own but for those who enjoy his films I am perfectly happy to admit that there is probably something I am not seeing.

Whether it's delivering some of the most frenetic and emotional scenes of the director's filmography or blisteringly spattering walls with juicy, juicy gushes of gore, 'Django Unchained' is hands down Tarantino's most consistently satisfying movie. The inspired mashing of an old-school Western (set on the opposite coast) with blaxploitation snazz clicks immediately, and though the depiction of slavery might border on good taste, its ultimately empowering, viciously vengeful angle wins out in the end thanks to Christoph Waltz, Jamie Foxx, and the rest of the great cast's affectingly weighty performances.

Tarantino is bound to break the chains that he restricts himself from, but this is not that kind of a film, there is another way out.

Django Unchained

Tarantino's novelization of a comic book genre into a gritty satirical drama is another forward pass on his career that breathes the essence of old style literary work. And I emphasise on the word "novelization". Since for the first time, his film feels more like a book than a script. Just take the scene where Samuel L. Jackson calls out for Leonardo DiCaprio from the dinner table where the crowd is enchanted in Christoph Waltz's charm. Such a scene is often lopped out from a script that is to make it to the screen and instead some other element is added to boost the script and the pace of the film.

But the writer and director of the western superhero flick Quentin Tarantino insists on going through the social rigmarole as an excuse of understudying the history. And you are up for it. That's what baffles me the most. Why have we been ignoring the lectures and documentaries and books so blatantly but consistently fails to even speculate his views on those very subjects. We are chugging it up unapologetically, repetitively. That is because, Tarantino knows what he adores about the history and what will gather and please the crowd, the most. And it is not just that he infuses the facts into narration that goes unnoticed.

It cannot just be the smoothness. It is actually the best aspect of the historical events, the so called highlights, and it is the characteristics of the characters and even the world they revolve around. He uses those tools to convert those facts into a myth casting spell upon spell on us, just like he bombards us with whistle blowing one-liners, slapstick humor and guns blazing across the room. Addition to that, you can see him using his reputation and credibility in Django Unchained by casting a cast of such caliber and more importantly using those tools into narrative that celebrates the cinema life that he lives and breathes for.

Django and Dr. Schultz walk into a room to meet the antagonist Mr. Candie. In the room there are two slaves on the ground wrestling with their owners edging them on, the scene is initially tense In Supreme writing, acting, and execution, Quentin Tarantino again creates a modern masterpiece with his film Django Unchained. Quentin Tarantino has managed to reinvent the spaghetti western genre with a blend of dark humor and dramatic storytelling while also acknowledging and portraying the horrors of American slavery. In one particular scene, however, is quickly diffused when Candie stylishly give Schultz a nod of approval after brief questioning and offers him a seat. 
	The scene builds tension again when Django has to sit at a bar and not only listen to the brutal fighting, but also approve of it to keep his cover. The scene comes to a bloody and conclusion as one slave putting out the eyes of his opponent, all while the spectators watch on, black and white alike. Scenes similar to this are frequent in Django Unchained, characters do very little to stop the horrors that occur, and sometimes cheer it on. 
While on the surface Django may seem overindulgent in violence, it also serves an ironic twist on the viewer, who may be horrified with the inaction of characters, but enjoys the violence all the same. Ironically, Tarantino is critiquing the acceptance of violence he so often creates. Tarantino has again taken another common film genre and added his unique trademark to it, however controversial the subject matter may be.

I'm at a point in my Tarantino affair that I want to see him do something different. Maybe that's a bad idea because he is the best at doing what he does. However, as much as I loved Django Unchained, I am at a point where I'm finding (probably trying too hard actually) flaws. QTs formula is a unique story, colorful, yet brilliant dialogue, a couple of long build-ups to super tense situations that engross the viewer and perfect endings. He is simply one of the best. Hands down. However, with Django Unchained, while there were tense moments, they weren't nearly the level of the adrenaline shot in Pulp Fiction, the opening scene to Inglorious Basterds or the latter's basement bar scene. Django is a fantastic film that is quintessential Tarantino. The dialogue is fantastic. The acting of every major character is unmatched. Yet, because it lacked those crucial tense moments that made me feel the same way I have before inTarantino flicks, it does make me wonder if he has worn out his formula and needs to pull a Scorsese and do a film like "Hugo." Then again, if he just isn't capable of doing that, I'd watch as many Djangos as QT wants to film since, really, it is better than 99% of the crap out there.

Dopo una filmografia completa ed invidiabile anche dai registi pi√π acclamati, Tarantino torna a stupire con questo esplosivo western, che lo conferma uno dei migliori registi della storia. L'aspetto che sorprende di pi√π, come ogni suo film, √® la sceneggiatura, cruda, intensa ed esplicita, intrattiene dall'inizio alla fine facendo scorrere la storia con una fluidit√† fuori dal comune. Le quasi tre ore di film volano in un batter d'occhio: il coinvolgimento emotivo e visivo funziona dall'inizio alla fine, facendo letteralmente volare il tempo davanti ai nostri occhi. Lo stile dell'eccentrico regista fa sentire la sua pesante e piacevole influenza, con inquadrature spinte al limite e scene coraggiosissime ma memorabili. La presenza di numerosi colpi di scena crea una suspense che non lascia mai la presa verso lo spettatore, il quale si ritrova in una condizione di continua angoscia verso i preziosi personaggi a cui si √® affezionato. In generale lo ritengo un film storico, una pietra miliare del cinema moderno che verr√† ricordato negli anni, per il suo stile unico, per la passione di cinema che trasuda e per la perfetta esecuzione sotto tutti gli aspetti.

Oh man, so well done!! So many insanely good performances! I just want to ask Leonard if his performance was based on someone he knows because he made some very distinctive choices. For those that would be sensitive (no judgement) this is a very violent movie, and there are scenes that are going to take pieces of your heart as they should because they are based on the awful historical treatment of slaves. I think its important to say that Tarantino treats violence that is historical accurate with the respect and truth that is needed to remember them; the violence that is fancy is over the top theatrical (sort of an "alienation of the audience" so that you can just enjoy the emotional cathartic-ness of a wishful-thinking, cowboy sort of justice). The only disappointment (SPOILER ALERT) is that I wish Calvin Candy would have died a more horrible death. I get that it was really his ego being shot (couldn't believe HE was actually being shot) but still. After the dog scene and the fighting scene when we meet him, I want MORE to happen to him . . . a lot more.

This is another Tarantino masterpiece and you are either going to love it or hate it, but if you have seen other Tarantino films you know what to expect walking into the cinema - buckets of blood, dark humour, priceless cameos and razor sharp dialogue. The only surprise element is the romance. Even though Django gets as down and dirty as the "baddies" he is doing it for loooove. Ahhh.

In a nutshell

Django is a slave in the American South. When he is freed by a bounty hunter, Dr Schultz, they form an unlikely alliance. They spend the winter killing people for money, then get down to the real business at hand - freeing Django's wife and taking sweet revenge.

Mood of the film

Pulp Fiction, but in a Wild West setting. No wait, Inglourious Basterds, but in a Wild West setting. Okay, I give up. It is a Tarantino western, people! It is insane.

Best performances

It is a tie between Django's (Foxx) intensity, Dr Schultz's (Waltz) panache and Candie's (DiCaprio) malice. (Samuel L Jackson's housekeeper, Stephen, was too much of a caricature.) I vote for Christoph Waltz. He is more magnetic than Foxx and certainly more subtle than DiCaprio.

Stand-out scene

Eish. One of the most horrific, chilling scenes I have ever seen is surely the Mandingo fighting sequence. Two slaves are made to fight each other to the death. They do so in the lounge by the fireplace, surrounded by "gentlemen" drinking cognac, smoking cigars and chit-chatting.

Negatives

I do not mind Tarantino's penchant for squirting blood, but it does not do anything for me either. It has been done, Quentin, move on.

Is it relevant today?

It certainly touches on issues that are still relevant in society, such as a group of people being treated as second-rate citizens, violence perpetrated against women, etc.

Tarantino has been criticised for the violence in the film. His reply is that there is a big difference between the violence dished out by the baddies and the justice that Django serves up. The audience is supposed to know the one is cruel and unjustified and evil, while the other is pure and fun because it is revenge. I have to admit, I did distinguish between the two types of violence, and I did root for Django when he was doing the shooting, but whether that is acceptable is quite another story.

Does it cop out?

Has Tarantino ever shied away from any issue, from any controversy? I mean, he killed Hitler in Inglourious Basterds!

FYI

During filming Christoph Waltz fell off his horse and broke his pelvis. Jamie Foxx subsequently gave him a saddle with a seat belt.

Django Unchained stars Jamie Foxx, Christoph Waltz and Leonardo DiCaprio, and it is directed by the one and only Quentin Tarantino. Not to mention that this is his first western flick. It takes place in the early 1900s and is about a slave played by Jamie Foxx who makes a deal with Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz) to help him find a group of people and to find his wife. Django Unchained blew me away in every way possible. It was extremely well written, (Obviously. It's Tarantino) well acted, It looked beautiful and the direction was out-standing. I could not find a single thing that I disliked! Everything was perfect! It's hard to determine the genera. It's mostly a movie about slavery, but it has the setting of a western. I guess that it could be considered a southwestern movie :) The two main protagonists have good chemistry. One is a slave who will do anything to get his wife back. The other is a man who cares for him and just needs his help. Watching these characters grow together as a team was quite an experience. Especially because Django is a slave, and back then, it was unusual to treat a slave with kindness. The antagonist that we are introduced to is Calvin Candie. (Leo's role) He is a very successful slave owner and has a large cotton plantation. He pulls off a fantastic performance. There is one scene when he smashes a glass on a table and he actually starts bleeding on set, but he continues to compose good acting. The character himself was a very unlikable character in all of the right reasons. I absolutely loved this villain.

Literally the only thing to like about this film is the acting, (specifically by Christoph Waltz and Leonardo DiCaprio) and the cinematography. Otherwise the corny plot and outrageous inaccuracies (I know Quieten Tarantino doesn't even try to be accurate, but still **cringe**) make this film nearly unwatchable.

Have you ever wondered why slaves never fought there master or what would happen if they had the chance to. The movie "Django Unchained" explores this idea. It is a story of a slave gaining freedom and ultimately freeing his wife from slavery and in the process takes down a famous slave plantation Candy land. The movie starts with Django being a slave but he is rescued from slavery by a german bounty hunter named Dr Schultz. He practiced dentistry for a while but then became a bounty hunter. He needed Djangos to help him locate the briddle brothers who were slavers. Dr Schultz takes him through this journey and they track down the briddle brother two of which Django himself killed and whipped and before killing one of them he says to the salves "yall wanna see something" and blows his brains out. He is then recruited but the Dr to be a bounty hunter for the winter and the thought of killing white people for money was very interesting to Django. He became very talented in shooting. After the winter he tells Dr Schultz that he wants to free his wife Broomhilda whose name the Dr recognized because of her german name. She ends up being in candy land the famous slave plantation. They go to candyland to save Hilda and they come up with a terrific plan. The plan goes south after they are caught by Mr candy's trusted friend who was a former slave named stephen. Dr schultz is killed but Django get into a big shootout with them and kills a lot of white slavers. He is captured but escapes and comes back to candy and slaughters all the white people in the plantation and also stephen the former slave.
This movie makes me think of what it would have been like if slaves had rebelled and gone out after there master and try to kill them. You can imagine the pain the slaves felt but they never fought back. This movie unleashed the pain the slaves felt to white people in very violent way but get the idea across that slaves at that time would smile and the death of a white man who was their slave owner. The movie makes us think could white people endure the pains black people went through if they were slaves. There a scene where Django had to watch a slave who was refusing to fight being fed to dogs to die and this hits home hard because I could never imagined being in that position. The movie though violent makes you feel, or at least for me a little bit of hatred towards white and in some cases you'll find yourself smiling when Django slaughters all the slavers. I love the setting being the west but the town is greenville tennessee which was  a big slave town even after the abolishment of slavery. The movie show the west in the eye of a black man and a foreigner. It shows how america treated the those who were not of the country. Overall the movie is very eye opening and just show that slavery was a very disturbing time in the history of the us and we have come a long way. But we also have a long way to go.

Separated from his wife and send for slave auction in the Deep South two years before the civil war, Django's (Jamie Foxx) brutal history with his former owners captures the attention of German-born bounty hunter Dr. Schultz (Christoph Waltz).

Posing as a dentist, the unorthodox Schultz commandeers Django on his death-march-to-market on the knowing that Django has information on the whereabouts and can personally identify his wanted dead-or-alive current targets, the murderous Brittle brothers.

In return for his cooperation, Schultz offers freedom from slavery and training for a job as the first black bounty hunter. Fixated on finding his wife Broomhilda (Kerry Washington), Django makes quick work of locating the Brittles earning his freedom and a tidy sum of money. 

Instead of going their separate ways, Schultz offers to assist Django in finding and rescuing his wife. Refining Django's hunting skills and providing vital access to information, their search ultimately leads them to the slyly-charming and brutal Mississippi plantation owner, Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio). 

Exploring the compound under false pretenses, Django and Schultz arouse the suspicion of Candie's trusted house slave, Stephen (Samuel L. Jackson). Marked and measured, they must choose between independence and solidarity, between sacrifice and survival. 

Nominated for five Oscars, iconic writer/ director Quentin Tarantino's first western is an intriguing narrative about life, liberty and the pursuit of vengeance. Tarantino's trademark flair for dramatics and violence sit well in the pseudo-genre.

Waltz once again shines under Tarantino's direction, a true master in the art of line delivery, everything about him screams presence. Jamie Foxx's performance is slightly overdone and calculated almot to the point where it looks as though he is acting, rather than embodying. Jackson (as always) brings a little sparkle to his purpose written characters, adding levity but also insight. Whilst DiCaprio, whom has always had my curiosity (if not my personal taste) finally caught my attention with the perfect balance of smarmy and sneaky, enough so to make me forget it was in fact him. 

A major miscalculation in performance however was Tarantino's own cameo. All most as if it was thrown in at the last moment, he attempts to match our own John Jarratt's accent in a bizarre ill-fitting mess of vocal gymnastics that is beyond laughable and detracts attention from the last 15 minutes of suspense.

The Verdict: Although a decent film from one of the most distinctive directors, I wouldn't put Django Unchained even in his top five. Personally, I think my 165 min would have been better spent revisiting cult classic Reservoir Dogs or the unique Inglorious Bastards; and I think other projects will take the Oscars on offer for the same reason.

Review of Django (the "D" is silent)

	Well, Django is certainly a Tarantino movie, but in my opinion, it is also one of his finest works (behind Pulp fiction, of course). Although I have to admit, sometimes the jury still seems to be out on Tarantino's style; this movie makes a definite case in his favor. Nevertheless, the story is one that is both timeless and novel at the same time. Classic man seeking lost love, but this man happens to be s freed slave bounty hunter, killin all the white folks that are deservin' of a killin' with the help of his German friend and benefactor. Beyond the story, however, Tarantino also solidifies his role as the modern epic storyteller sparing none of the gory, boring, long, beautifully shot details. Somehow it all works. The modern western epic is here to stay with Django (and eventually Hateful 8). Is Django perfect? No. If it was perfect would it truly be a Tarantino film? Again, I say no. Much like the Japanese principle of wabi-sabi, this film has a certain something that isn't quite right, but makes it oh, so memorable (although some-times maybe just a tad too memorable). But here I think there is the right amount (give or take a liter of blood) of Tarantino uniqueness without being totally overboard. Is it a life changing drama covering unspoken hot-button transcendental subjects; well, yes and no; in a Tarantino sort of way. In summary, it is long, but it moves and is, quite plainly, a good movie
	Another thing that really pulls this movie together is the acting. Tarantino as usual, formulates the perfect balance between strange and just plain talented actors and actresses A wonderful amount of convincing acting comes from Mr. Foxx. Mr. Jackson is as talented as ever (perhaps too good) as the cranky old slave. Oh, and did I mention Leonardo Di Caprio... enough said. In short, the story combined with the incredible acting make a worthy flick
	What really seals the deal, however, is the incredible cinematography. Tarantino really finds himself at home in the incredible vistas of the near-west and south in ante-bellum America. I hope that you are able to find yourself in an IMAX for this bad boy. I think that this is really what licks the envelope for me. It should be noted that this doesn't rid the movie of the necessary Tarantinoisms. Story, talent, and technically beautiful. And as an extra add on Tarantino's choice in soundtrack is as eclectic and oddly appropriate as ever. I will give this movie the solid "really should see (aka 8.5/10). Enjoy.

The beauty of Tarantino's films is that he can glean the finest qualities from lesser works and synthesize them into something even greater than the sum of their parts.

The frustrating aspect of his work is that one gets the impression that even in doing so, he has only up to this point been scratching the surface of that which is possible from that intellect.

I hope that his assertion that he's doing only two more films and then is retiring is baseless and thoroughly untrue. In saying that, I must admit that I enjoyed his ode to the spaghetti westerns of days gone by and that using that template as a mirror to the great racial divide that has splintered America to its core since its beginning and has stayed unchanged was nothing short of audaciously brilliant.
