Django Unchained is a classic Tarantino movie, blending powerful music with mosaic scenes and wonderfully scripted dialogue. Splicing the scenes to create a certain rhythm and story is a talent of Tarantino's rampant in his recent movies. However, he almost pushes his limits here by over-glorifying himself and overlooking the small things. He is getting cocky and too sure of himself. There was not as much deliberate calculation as seen in Inglorious Bastards and Reservoir Dogs. The ending is too nicely wrapped up, with a cliche close. Yes this could be a nod to the spaghetti westerns' styles, however, the ease of success becomes too implausible and detracts from the story's validity. That said, Foxx, DiCaprio and Waltz stole the show and deserve all accolades for their performances. A movie rife with talent on many ends and executed in a nearly perfect way.

I'm at a point in my Tarantino affair that I want to see him do something different.  Maybe that's a bad idea because he is the best at doing what he does.  However, as much as I loved Django Unchained, I am at a point where I'm finding (probably trying too hard actually) flaws.  QTs formula is a unique story, colorful, yet brilliant dialogue, a couple of long build-ups to super tense situations that engross the viewer and perfect endings.  He is simply one of the best.  Hands down.  However, with Django Unchained, while there were tense moments, they weren't nearly the level of the adrenaline shot in Pulp Fiction, the opening scene to Inglorious Basterds or the latter's basement bar scene.  Django is a fantastic film that is quintessential Tarantino.  The dialogue is fantastic.  The acting of every major character is unmatched.  Yet, because it lacked those crucial tense moments that made me feel the same way I have before inTarantino flicks, it does make me wonder if he has worn out his formula and needs to pull a Scorsese and do a film like "Hugo."  Then again, if he just isn't capable of doing that, I'd watch as many Djangos as QT wants to film since, really, it is better than 99% of the crap out there.

"Django Unchained'' is a film I missed in 2012 that I've finally been able to see. I have not seen many of Quentin Tarantino's films, but I know he has made many iconic films such as "Pulp Fiction''. This film is so confident in itself you can ignore the minor issues and just have fun watching the gunfights, and the performances. Jammie Foxx does a brilliant job as Django. He just owns the role completely. Alongside him stands the good doctor (Christoph Waltz) and the evil slave owner Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio). Waltz does a great job as the quirky and odd doctor, and he and Foxx have great chemistry. DiCaprio plays for the first time, a character I hated. He did such a sublime job at playing this rich southern slave owner. I cheered internally when he met his demise. 

   The film has so many different vibes. For the most part, it balances the comedy, drama, and bloody action perfectly. This is the only western film that can do what it does. I  kid you not, there is a rap song twice in this film during an action scene. 

   "Django Unchained" was not at all what I expected. From start to finish I was entertained by this funny, bloody, quirky western driven by tremendous performances and great direction from Tarantino.

The only problem I have with this movie is the scene with Tarantino himself in it. He really brings the film down with his phenomenally bad acting. 
But apart from this the film is so well written and Christoph waltz steals every scene he is in. He is such an amazing actor absolutely deserved the Oscar. No competition

Easily one of Tarantino's best features yet, "Django Unchained", manages to truly capture the feel of a western film, albeit with a Tarantino standard amount of violence and absurd humor. The film packs an amazing emotional punch as well, adding to the sense that Django is a slave who has truly had everything taken from him. Amazing performances among the cast, particularly Christoph Waltz's role as charismatic bounty hunter King Schulz, help make this film all the more enjoyable. The film has an interesting amount of detail to time and environment unlike any I've seen, giving you the sense that even during the slowest parts of the film time still passes by, and people still do things in the world. This movie is truly an instant classic and should be viewed at least twice to truly take in every thing it has to offer. -ACR Recommended & Approved

Quentin Tarantino is nothing if not extravagantly entertaining in his neo-grindhouse style. He uses the vintage studio logos, big bold text, spaghetti western music, and water-balloon-like blood bags of exploding gristle. Know what you're getting into and enjoy the hell out of it.

Tarantino knows how to tell a blood-soaked vengeance tale- we know this from Kill Bill. There's something in us as movie-goers that will always love to see the bad guys do bad things, then get their comeuppance. This film is no different, and it just oozes cool. It finds that magic spot of taking something just past the point of being silly to being somehow awesome.

As evil as Christoph Waltz was in Inglourious Basterds, he is equally good and badass in this film. He deserved that Oscar. Such a great character.

DiCaprio, playing the rare villain role, chews the scenery and pulls off being the guy you "love to hate." That means he did something right.

Jaime Foxx filled the leading role well enough, he certainly has the physicality for the role- but his dialogue delivery suffers a bit. I almost wanted to say to him "speak up," like he was restraining his voice. Weird.

And if course, Samuel L. Jackson kills it. Plain and simple. 

This is an explosively violent, cleverly written, anachronistically bold musically, strangely funny "Spaghetti-Southern" with an incredible supporting cast. Great film.

I have tried to enjoy Quentin Tarantino's movies in the past, rarely did I finish them. Yet I was surprised to find Django Unchained not only bare able but one of the best movies I had seen in ages. The script was the perfect balance of humour and intelligence. DiCaprio was fascinating in his role and Christoph Waltz instantly likeable. Foxx was good however his character was crowded out but how fantastic the other two were. Every scene with these three was gripping and tense. It did get typically silly for the final moments, however the rest of the movie was so far above par that it became forgivable.

This is very Tarantino, so has memorable riveting scenes,  great dialogue and interesting characters.  That being said,  revenge is all that really drives this movie forward and it is tough to get on the blood train as the villain is so cartoonish.

Django wasn't what I expected. I was expecting a serious action western. However, with director Quentin Tarantino, I should've know better. The movie was action packed and had intense fighting sequences, but they were portrayed in a way that was almost humorous. The sound effects were exaggerated and the blood was excessive. The acting was terrific. Jamie Foxx did a great job as Django. Christoph Waltz and Leonardo DiCaprio did great jobs portraying their characters as well. Waltz especially did a phenomenal job in making very intense and suspenseful scenes comical. All in all a great film with a great crew!

You can't and Tarantino I hope you continue to make great films because they are mesmerizing.

White guilt is the only reason critics fair 12 years a slave over the evidently superior Django Unchained. Fair dos, 12 years is beautifully shot and features powerful performances, but its pointlessly misery inducing. 

As if you need to convince any clear thinking 21st century citizen that slavery is wrong. We know its wrong, we know racial discrimination is wrong. Granted, not everybody accepts these truths, which is more of the reason why Django Unchained is the better film about slavery as it more immediate in its message. 

Things might be different if (institutionalised) slavery was still a big thing in America. Maybe then would 12 years' approach be more the appropriate. But in an age where the urge to hate for no decent reason is hidden behind more widely accepted moral codes and propagated subversively when fear its at its most potent, presenting "truthfully" this bigoted and dark, dark period is not going to do any good in enforcing the message that this sort of behaviour is not acceptable. Racist people and similar scum nowadays claim not to be what they are and the worst of the worst don't even acknowledge their evil. They don't know they are evil,  a "Banal" attitude when guilt no longer effects and they just act because its all they know. 

The same attitude aristo wannabe Candie sports where he is totally unaware of his own villainy; to the point where he takes major offence when Django and Schultz try to steal back Broomhilda from him. He is so blissfully unaware of his obvious moral lapses that he takes severe umbrage to Django and Schultz' actions. HE thinks he is the one who has been wronged. This is the dark heart of human evil pumping strong, loud and proud without shame of any kind. 

This is what makes Django the better film, how Tarantino highlights the absurdity of the situation and goes to a certain extent explaining how such an institution as slavery could thrive so prosperously in an admittedly still very young nation which founded itself on ideals of freedom and democracy. Whereas 12 Years just showed it, Django explained it, then and now that this happens, its happened throughout all of history and will continue to happen and all we can do is fight those who strive to keep such ideas alive in our society. 

On this basis, i'd even say Django is even the more humanist film than 12 Years, the braver therefore, the smarter as well and sure as hell the more entertaining. It also has the benefit of being an actual cinematic work and not just an unoriginal two hour TV special.

Django Unchained is the latest film from Quentin Tarantino, of Pulp Fiction and Kill Bill fame.  He is a filmmaker known for smart dialogue, brutal violence, and various over the top indulgences.  This film does nothing to break that trend.  Anyone going into this film should know what they will be getting.  This film should be viewed as a bloody action, suspense, humor, hybrid that is over 2 and a half hours long.  This is not "12 Years a Slave."  That film is harrowing, realistic, and painful to watch.  Exposing the crime of slavery with no romanticism whatsoever.  This movie has extreme violence against African Americans as well, but it serves to set up the cathartic desserts that are served at the end of the film.
The acting, as to be expected in a Quentin Tarantino film, consistently hits the mark.  With the exception being Kerry Washington, who really isn't given much to do in the scenes she is featured.  Leonardo DiCaprio is mesmerizing as plantation owner Calvin J Candie, whose genteel nature is just a ruse for a heartless, vicious temperment. Just as exciting to watch is Samuel L. Jackson, the very definition of an Uncle Tom who appears harmless at first glance and is anything but.  
This being a Tarantino joint, you are going to have to deal with some overlong scenes and one misplaced one, where a would be mob has an issue dealing with the eyeholes on their masks, seems like it should belong in Blazing Saddles instead of here.   However, on the whole the pacing here feels much better than in QT's last film, Inglorious Basterds.  
The extreme violence of this film cannot be overstated.  I do not know if "Mandingo" fighting was a real thing, but it is disturbing and very difficult to watch as presented here.  The scene also lets us know what kind of human being our heroes are about to deal with regarding Candie.  There is also another ultra-gory shootout that you may feel a little guilty to be thrilled by.  
I feel QT takes the revenge aspect a little to far in the end.  The whole mission of the film was for Django to get his wife back. He does, and then instead of getting out of Dodge while the getting is good he goes back to Candie's estate for one last, totally over the top confrontation with Samuel L. Jackson.  It becomes a little indulgent to say the least, you will be ready for the movie to end.  That said, there are a number of great moments and you will not mistake this film to be from any other filmmaker out there.  Score: 8.5

This film was brilliantly written and directed by Quentin Tarantino, who 
won the oscar for writing it.  It stars Jamie Foxx, Christoph Waltz (won best supporting oscar), Leonardo DiCaprio,  Samuel Jackson (in another great and unusual villainous performance) and Kerry Washington.  It has been called a Western, because it takes place in Mississippi circa 1860.  This film is about a freed slave who partners with a bounty hunter, and also searches for his wife, who was sold to a different owner.  The film was criticized for use of the 
"n-word", but it is about as moving and convincing a statement against slavery as had ever been made.  The film is full of violence and blood, like many Tarantino movies, but none of it was gratuitous or unnecessary.  This is a great movie in a time where the film business has been in a prolonged slump.  The film is highly entertaining, gripping, riveting, heart-wrenchingly moving, and probably the best movie made in the previous 10 years.  Tarantino's method of story-telling, and his use of high comedy to clearly expose the foolishness of human actions, harken one back to the great Mark Twain. With this film, Tarantino has solidified his place as the preeminent director of this era, and proven that he is a true genius.

I'm a big fan of Tarantino movies and a big fan of spaghetti westerns. As a result, I had very high hopes for this movie. In the end, I was a bit disappointed as it was only a very good Tarantino movie and not a great one.

This has Sergio Leone written all over it, the stylized music (even with the angelic ahhhhhh ahhhhhhhhh's), closeup, slow motion tension shots, stark cinematography nods, and so on.  If Leone has a corner on the market for spaghetti westerns, then Tarantino has himself the first great chitlin's southern. 

Jamie Fox is great as usual, but it's Christopher Walts' Dr. King Schultz who steals the show with his calm, courageous bounty hunter persona. It is a true joy to see him work his magic against the slave traders, the Marshall, and the plantation owner; a marvel to behold, as the doctor slowly calms and then dismantles his victims with logic and, so often, the lure of big money. It is the lure of big money and the inherent greed of those willing to talk "business" that is the final nail in the coffin for most of his "transactions." 

A fine movie from top to bottom. And considering the great injustice slaves went through, who can't enjoy a good white redneck being taken down in cold blood? No tears shed here, as most viewers would probably agree. That great joy can been seen especially in the best belly laugh Django has when the KKK members get blown to bits by a dynamite blast. 

Hey, there's even humor. The KKK who-made-the-eye-holes scene was a true belly laugh. And the doctor's smooth, even at times silly statements are a hoot as well: "My name is Dr.King Schultz, this is my valet, Django, and these are our horses, Fritz, and Tony." The dialogue throughout is priceless. 

The only issue I have with the film is the excessive blood, especially the ending  (and the water-melon-being-dropped splats! that pepper the film as blood, bone, and sinew fly). I also think the end was a bit overdone, the immovable plantation obliterated, but I guess it wouldn't be a Tarantino film without all the mayhem. A good watch indeed.

Quentin Tarantino makes great films, this is one of his greatest. An instant classic and a highlight for his career, Django unchains itself from comparison to any other film, it's magnificent characters, astonishingly detailed writing and moments of shock are so out there. Christoph Waltz can do no wrong, he is an actor with talent through the roof, and his latest performance as Dr. King Schultz catapults him further to one of the beat actors status, yes I am a fan. Same goes to Jamie Foxx, he plays vulnerable and unsure to start with yet as he gets closer to the end of his revenge journey as Django, he becomes confident abd flamboyant, Foxx is impeccable here. Leonardo DiCaprio is almost unrecognizable in terms of behavior and attitude, he is superb as a nasty piece of work Calvin Candy, a slave ranch owner. Samuel L Jackson, Walton Goggins and Kerry Washington add more star power to this marvel of a movie, Tarantino's writing and characters here at what drive this adventure, yet the intensity amd horror of slavery also has strong authority onscreen amongst the stars, as well as some exciting moments of action and well staged gun fights. This western themed revenge tale dowses the genre in signature Tarantino fire igniting a 165 minute masterpiece.

A Quentin Tarantino film about a bounty hunter (Christoph Waltz) who frees a slave (Jamie Foxx) and the two unleash violence across the South. Waltz, nominated for Best Supporting Actor, steals almost every scene and carries this movie from town to town. Strong performances delivered by Leo DiCaprio and Samuel L. Jackson--but both don't appear until too l...ate in the movie. My 'Tarantino watermark' remains "Pulp Fiction" and this movie doesn't rise to that level of film-making; after a sluggish start it's not until the last hour that this picture reaches a full gallop. At times the film takes on a distinct feel as a spoof to viewers taking us back to the 1960s westerns. The music was above average and perhaps the movie's best quality. Overall, I expected better from Tarantino and left disappointed for an Academy Award 'Best Picture' nominee. Grade: DB- The D is silent.

Django Unchained is filmmaker Quenton Tarantino's latest off-beat adventure for the big screen. Highlighting this film are great performances by Christoph Waltz, Jamie Foxx, Samuel L. Jackson and an ensemble supporting cast that includes former television stars Don Johnson, Tom Wopat, Bruce Dern, Don Stroud and Amber Tamblyn. However, it is the sharp performance of Leonardo DiCaprio as the cruel and merciless plantation owner Calvin Candie that steals the show in this violent tale set in the south prior to the civil war. Inspired by the 1966 Italian made western Django, Tarantino wrote a script for this film that accent and combine his unique style of filmmaking with the "spaghetti western" genre while presenting an eye-opening look at slavery in the deep- south during that period. In typical Tarantino fashion this movie was not made for the faint of heart with its extreme graphic depiction of violence and torture...so be warned. Even though this movie runs long at just under 3 hours it maintains your interest at a high level.

I'm definitely surprised at the amount I enjoyed Django Unchained, considering I am no Tarantino fan and I'm not into historical uber-fiction either. The plot loses me quite a bit in the second act, devolving into the more blood soaked orgy that Tarantino is famous for. But the first half was a superbly written masterpiece that very often had me in the moment, with no idea of where the train was actually headed. Christoph Waltz's character was particularly intriguing, pairing quick wit with gun-slinging skills. The sequence with the klansman complaining about having difficultly riding with the bags over their faces was just the most ridiculous, hilarious, and brilliant part of the entire film. I could certainly have done with a little less race language, though I suppose there's never such as thing as "just the right amount" of the n-word in a movie, and it's not like it was out of context.

You gotta love Quentin Tarantino. He can make even the simplest stories so damn entertaining and memorable that he can make a classic film out of an established story technique. He makes a revenge film and we get Kill Bill, a World War II film about Jews killing Nazis that we've seen in Inglorious Basterds; when he finally got to show his interpretation of the Western, Spaghetti Western and Blaxploitation genre, we get the modern masterpiece that is Django Unchained.

"Django Unchained" is a very interesting, well-edited, well-directed and acted film, but it's also an uncomfortable film. Whether you have a problem with the violent depiction of slavery, the idea of a slave hero taking revenge, the torture that's shown, the death, or the blood, it just doesn't go down easy. As an action film it works rather well, and the fact that Django (Foxx) is out for vengeance against those that have wronged him and his wife, makes it one of the better motivated films about revenge. It also puts traditionally shown torture in exploitation films into a new context, as it's realistic and historically accurate, which only adds to the unsettling quality of the film. Christoph Waltz gives an amazing performance as a character that so rarely gets written or shown onscreen. Leonardo DiCaprio is very malevolent as Calvin Candie, showing us a villain that is almost unknowing of the absolute cruelty he inflicts, while also being arrogant, pompous, and spoiled. As a dandy he is nothing but interesting, although much more awe-inspiring is Samuel L. Jackson as the head house slave Stephen. His performance was incomparable, obviously the more complex and entertaining villain, even alongside Candie's absolute evilness. Stephen is both treacherous and crafty, unlike many villains seen before, and the fact that he betrays his own people makes him the more hated. The ending is where this film lost me. It kind of peters out here and there before gaining back its momentum, inevitably slowing to a grave pace at certain points. While the ending was significant in the awesomeness of the action, it felt tacked on in some way, less satisfying than if Django outright won, without consequence. That may seem selfish of me to say, and small minded, but a shootout would have felt better deserved.

The once-charismatic-counter-culture director of Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction has reached a new low point with Django, a film that styllistically might have a superficial resemblance with his old films, but is ultimately a pretty mainstream hollywood fantasy of the cool, good guys beating the caricature, bad ones with pomp (look at the finale sequence with the dynamite and Django's wife shutting her ears with a silly, theatrical gesture while the epic, spaghetti-western music reaches a climax). The film of course uses a lot of shots that are both a satire and a tribute to spaghetti westerns (like the very fast zoom-ins that give the film the kitsch quality of the old, Italian b-westerns) but Tarantino seems to use them for no other reason than to be playful. Under this post-modern, playful surface there is a very conventional plot, which pretends to be dealing with a serious subject like slavery. Gone are the daring plot structures of Pulp Fiction, gone the subtle black humor and the unexpected dialogue; in their place we see silly humor (like the guy who is shot repeatedly by his own guys in the mansion) and testicle-shooting jokes. Yes, the Christoph Waltz character is entertaining but not as much as his writer would like to think. But actually the problem transcends this film and has to do with the attitude of audiences today, who are uneducated in cinema (because they only watch films that are from 90s onwards) and see in the empty post-modernism of films such as this, intelligence; or mistake the countless references to other films (they haven't seen) for depth. This fake post-modernism under whose skin lies the wolf of a cheap, easily-digested philosopy of consumerist Hollywood has nothing revolutionary, despite selling itself as such. Tarantino's films were all style and no substance from the beginning of his carreer of course (and the self-consciousness of this was their strength), but now the style doesn't seem fresh anymore and the films are trying to be something more than empty style, they try to be meaningful in resolving conventionaly the tensions of the linear plot. The film could easily have the title Tarantino Enchained.

'Django Unchained' blurs the boundaries between western and gangster adventure, and does so pretty well. The tale follows the life of Django, as he manages to transform himself from a mere slave to one of the best gunsligners around. Whilst I never consider Fox for his acting, he portrayed the driven character convincingly. Alongside the excellent Waltz, they are a fine lead duo, cleverly ensuring that things almost always go in their favour. The film takes an interesting; if not expected turn, when they begin to pursue Django's love interest; the brilliantly named BroomHilda. From this point on the film steps up a notch in tension and excitement, due considerably to the ever brilliant DiCaprio. His portrayal of Calvin is amongst his best work (although I am beginning to use this phrase all too often). The somewhat psychotic character perhaps optimises those who possess great power and money during this era. The scene set around the dinner table is of great quality, particularly as the blood of Calivin' s hands is that of his own. I half expected the medics to come charging onto the screen, but it inevitably added to the performance. 

Humour also runs throughout which is more than welcome; albeit unexpected. Jonah Hill and Samuel L Jackson stand out, and keep everything relatively light-hearted. I did however think this element went somewhat too far, so as to detract from any tension or emotion. Whilst the shootout towards the end was amusing and somewhat exciting, it did seem too spoofy. However overall this was a very enjoyable watch, featuring multiple stand-out performances from the leads.
Django Unchained doesn't take any prisoners; it's loud, fun, extremely violent, and one of Tarantino's best films.

Django Unchained shows potential until the ending of the movie. At a very specific moment, Tarantino loses control of the film. As the movie derails into loud, annoying, over-the-top action, it loses any substance it may have earned. The film demonstrates the complete lack of respect Tarantino has for his audience. He expects people to enjoy gratuitous violence without any remote meaning. And sadly, looking at the success of the film, he's right.

Now it is not fair to say the whole movie was bad. While Django himself was boring and flat, Christoph Waltz was a joy to watch. But it was Leonardo DiCaprio who completely stole the show from the moment he was on screen. Great acting that fit the movie absolutely perfectly and created the best character in the film, by far. 

Everyone else in the film was completely forgettable. And as to Samuel L Jackson, I was just confused. There were no explanations, no meaning, and nothing to take away from his character. 

The only reason this film even deserves 2 stars is the fun, adventurous first three quarters of the movie. What could have been  a four star western was wasted with boring, meaningless, violence. If westerns want to be taken seriously, it has to be done better than this. 

Also, did I mention they put rap in it? 
Rap, in a western. Abysmal.

Django unchained is a great movie that while it is a really good Tarantino movie is actually quite flawed. This film has a very good cast and great acting, Jamie Foxx, Christoph Waltz, Leonardo Di Caprio, Kerry Washington and Samuel L Jackson. Everyone is amazing, especially Waltz, Di Caprio and Jackson. This film is very well directed by Quentin Tarantino. This film is really entertaining and I love the scenes of Django Schultz killing for money. This film is so gory and just tones of fun, although one of my problems is that while I do appreciate the two different types of violence Tarantino is using, over the top gory and fun like the candy land shootout and the more disturbing violence like the Mandingo fight or the dogs ripping apart the slave or Broomhilda being tortured. I'm fine with the violence and it's not like I couldn't watch any of it but at some points I don't feel the two times are handled too well. The candy land shootout is amazing. The soundtrack is very good and this film is just a lot of fun. However I think the films is just way too long. The film is nearly 3 hours, I mean Tarantino has made some long movies before but I think this film is just too long. The ending is in my opinion a big let down when compared to just how good the rest of the film was. There's a whole sequence involving Tarantino in an acting role as a miner. In my opinion that bit should have just been cut. For me the first two acts are fantastic but the third act is let down. However the amazing candy land shootout does somewhat make up for it. While Django Unchained is a great film I just don't think it's as good as Pulp Fiction, Kill Bill, Reservoir Dogs and Inglourious Basterds. However Django Unchained is still a great film with a dissapointing ending. A-

Wednesday, January 15, 2014

(2012) Django Unchained
WESTERN

 It's supposed to be a homage to the Spaghetti Westerns of Sergio Corbucci and Leone but after already seeing so many, I actually thought this film had no rhythm in terms of the storyline. Written and directed by Quentin Tarantino who writes great dialogue but it doesn't seem to belong to this film since the perception that wealthy residents of Mississippi speaking perfect English like they all have 100% IQs is unrealistic since it has always been a proven fact that throughout American history the state of Mississippi contains some of the less educated people of the United States Of America. No matter how long ago the film is based on some of the dialogue exchanges is similar to how some people speak here for theirs hardly a character that speak like how people used to speak during the 1800's and from the most racist state too.         

This is two movies and not one where at the first half is Django helping and aiding a German bounty hunter- the second half centers on bounty hunter Schultz helping Django retrieving his wife back from the Leo Di Caprio character.  Jamie Foxx stars as the title character Django who was initially walking along with a group as a slave until he was saved by a bounty hunter who calls himself Dr. King Schultz played by Christopher Waltz.  At this point we don't fully understand why he saved him, but it was for financial motivations, since Django happens to know who and where some the wanted men happened to be located- and they're wanted dead and alive which means that besides personified as not being likable characters because they're racist that they also perform other atrocities against whites.  Tarantino has shown many great ideas but for reason they're not well executed here, for instance at the beginning, Schultz defends himself from a couple of racist outlaws escorting the slaves who're walking with chains on their hands and feet.  Schultz then manages to shoot one person dead and killing the other outlaws horse.  The guy curses but doesn't try to slip his leg out of his dead horse, and as Schultz and Django are leaving, the other slaves then attack him.  This scene is baffling since throughout the years I've been watching Westerns and so forth ... and from what I know from real life, majority of them who're in that exact situation are able to pull or slip their leg out, but in this film, he's completely helpless and unable to do that. I mean, if you're going to make a movie, check if pulling one's leg out is not possible. 

And the scene after the Schultz and Django gather up their kills, how did Schultz know when and where a particular racist mob is going to come after them, for the movie never explains.  Nor do we know about how Schultz is able to know  whether or not other racist mobs are going to come after them just because most citizens at that particular time don't like the idea that Schultz is associating himself with someone who's supposed to be a slave.  I mean, what's stopping other mobs from other towns coming after them since some of the wanted people Schultz had killed also had friends as well for those 'wanted dead and alive' situations seems almost entirely blatant. And it's the result of Tarantino watching many "Spaghetti Westerns" and not so much American ones. And because Tarantino has a habit of duplicating certain scenes from other movies, some of them don't seem to be better than what I had already seen such as "Mandingo" and the gun scenes that is similar to "A Better Tomorrow II". Tarantino stuffs his characters with a lot of smart dialogue but they don't appear to belong to this film if viewers were to compare this with other Spaghetti westerns, you will find that many of it's dialogue especially the ones directed by Sergio Leone one will be able to see that the dialogue exchanges are always compromised with the Eastwood character saying the least. We don't see any of that done here.  Winner of 2 Oscars out of 5 nominations.

Finally, Tarantino has created a film that he has been paying homage to for so many years. Django Unchained is Tarantino's 7th film and still hasn't lost his touch. Sadly Django Unchained is not perfect, as it has problems.

Django Unchained follows the same approach that was applied to Kill Bill, driven by a clear end goal and uses a linear approach in telling it's story, despite a few flashbacks. Though similar, it is a major improvement from Kill Bill as Tarantino keeps our attention with it's quirky characters. Characters in this film are definitely a much needed depth, with a richer backstory, in comparison to his previous films. Though the story does somewhat touch on previous territory, like the Django being trained by Schultz similar to The Bride trained by Pai Mei and Bill, and also moments where characters are camping telling a story. The film is definitely a big film, with a story that spans on long periods of time and creating personal growth for the protagonist. It would have been more interesting, if Django Unchained explores more of his personal and physical journey of becoming a bounty hunter. The film's dialogue is quite fun and it plays around with the dialogue found in classic Westerns. I did enjoy the fact that Tarantino has written two characters that clash in personality, Schultz and Candie, as their conversations with one another especially towards the end was thrilling to watch. Great dialogue is being written for Schultz and Candie as they represent the most over the top characters in the film, aside from Samuel L. Jackson's character. The Schultz character is definitely a complex one, for a Tarantino film, as this character seems to be doing his bounty hunting job as he has a sense of morality, which is probably the main reason why Candie and him resent each other.

Django Unchained tackles the genre that Tarantino seems to be in love with the most, and it seems like this is a film he has always wanted to tell but because this is a Tarantino film, it doesn't stay on course with the traditional Westerns by exploiting a topic that is barely touched on in the genre or at least not commonplace within the mainstream films, slavery. This does make the film a bit controversial as not everyone can be comfortable with the topic and even to the point of being offended. Both Inglourious Basterds and this film, touch on history but they don't ever become a social commentary or it never places the situation on trial, rather it is just used as a backdrop. Tarantino avoids having his characters become a representation of the cultures within that era. If you want to watch a film that touches on these themes with depth and fueled by a message, then watch Steve McQueen's 12 Years A Slave, but if you want to see a fun film then watch Django Unchained. This film in a way follows Kill Bill's approach in it's story, with a clear end goal, but this film balances the style and substance much better with it being consisted throughout the entire film. Django Unchained strays away from Tarantino's common use of the non-linear narrative and leans on to the conventional 3 act approach but keeping it feeling fresh due to his style. There are 2 scenes that were done so well that they deserve a mention, these scenes are the KKK segment and the Dining Room scene with the principal characters.

Robert Richardson returns to work with Tarantino and their collaboration always seems to give off positive results and this is mainly due to the understanding of each other's vision. Both have created a look that is reminiscent of the classic Westerns, using a warm palette to create the atmosphere and softer shots, in order to have the audience feel immersed to the era. The film also contains the quick zooms and close ups that were found in the films that this is paying homage to. With each subsequent film, Tarantino's budget and trust from the studios seem to rise which allows him to be ambitious in his work using multiple locations to film and build up faithful and detailed production sets. As the characters in this film have much more depth than Tarantino's previous film, the photography was able to convey that depth to these characters which then sells the character's motivations.

Similarly to his previous film, Tarantino has taken a soundtrack approach rather than hiring a composer to create an original score for the film. The tracks he chose though are score driven and again chooses the tracks that are either from Morricone or at least similar. That does allow the film to feel like a Leone film at times. Tarantino interestingly enough has used Hip-Hop/Rap music on certain moments but it comes off more as humorous, which allows the audience to not take the film too seriously and maintaining that fun upbeat tone.

Django Unchained may not be an ensemble film like Inglourious Basterds but this is due to the story being a bit more grounded and personal. Jamie Foxx as Django was a decent choice but he didn't really create something astonishing here with the character or maybe he was severely overshadowed by the acting performances from Waltz and DiCaprio. This is definitely the best that I have seen from Kerry Washington but it doesn't seem to be enough for me to highly appreciate it. Christoph Waltz and Leonardo DiCaprio on the other hand was a stand out in this film delivering performances that will always be remembered when people look back at their filmography. Waltz was able to come off as charming which makes him so likeable and he delivers his lines with amazing grace. DiCaprio creates this menacing character but at the same time able to give off a sense that he is a phony and a bit of a try hard. Samuel L Jackson was great in this, with an introduction to a character that will leave you surprised on how unlikable this person is.

Django Unchained is a fun Western film that I have been waiting for him to make since he started his film career. It contains amazing performances and great direction from Quentin Tarantino. Yes, Django Unchained could have been better but it has enough great moments for this to be in the stronger side in the director's filmography.

I liked this movie, the characters and the story built over time and the scenery and attention to detail was just great. You really hate the villains, which I think is getting harder and harder to do these days.

Jackson was too much, maybe the purpose of that character was to make you angry, but hey, the black racist was even more racist than Calvin Candie (DiCaprio). We have a lot of blood at the end, to satisfy the need of brutal action that we lost throughout the movie; it was a positive trait though. The sacrifice of Schultz was unnecessary, even when it increased the quality of hero that Django already had (now he's not only reclaiming his girl, now he's taking revenge for his friend). One of only two Tarantino films that I sincerely did not like at all. I was 25 years old when Pulp Fiction came out and remember thinking that it was one of the most fresh and original films I had ever seen; I loved every minute of it. The Kill Bills were clever and inventive, and for me, Inglorious Basterds was perfection. I mention these things because I truly "get" where Tarantino is headed most of the time with his art's direction, but I think he completely sold out the younger generation with Django. Mind you, I am no champion for black rights, but I found the use of Rick Ross and Tupac in the soundtrack for a 19th century film to be not only a bit disrespectful, but incredibly nonsensical and merely a thinly veiled attempt to draw in the Millenniels. Whereas the over the top violence worked well in the Kill Bill's, it was certainly ill placed in a movie concerning slavery. Leo was awesome, as was Don Johnson and Jackson, but Jamie Fox seemed to walk through the role mimicking his worst Clint Eastwood impression possible.

As with most of Tarantino's films, there's a LOT here to love. His homage to Spaghetti Westerns, the performances of Foxx, Waltz, DiCaprio and others, some tremendous scenes (especially the ManDingo sequences, the unbearably tense dinner at CandyLand, the brilliant, brilliantly funny dissection of the KKK), and generally excellent craft in every department.

BUT...

Even by QT's standards this is waaay too long. Probably 45 minutes too long. Almost nothing seems to happen for nearly an hour in the first half of the film. The dialogue isn't a patch on some of his best films, and the whole thing is massively self-indulgent. The final scenes are simply ridiculous: if you thought the slaughter at the end of  Kill Bill pt1 was gruesome, you ain't seen nothing. The very last shots are awful; utterly trivial and (IMHO) a huge misjudgement of tone that undermines some of the serious depiction of slavery and brutality he's lingered on for the previous 163 minutes. They nearly ruined the whole thing for me (but by then my patience was already gone...!).

Tarantino's latest film is, shall we say, over-ripe. Of course, the film is too long and generally in bad taste (focused on slavery and bounty-hunting in 1858). In the past, I might have rewarded a director who leaves the throttle open and goes for the gusto on all fronts, but I've never been one for the spurting blood capsule brand of violence and the use of the N-word (apparently 109 times) is patently ridiculous (if not also offensive).  Nevertheless, when you set those things aside (if you can), then I think we can see that Tarantino has a masterful touch as a director who pays attention to the tempo and pacing of scenes, to the suspense that can be generated through camera movement, cutting, and, of course, his trademarked dialogue.  He creates incredible set-pieces that are set apart by purposeful lulls (in this film, shot against nature's majestic beauty in some cases, or beauty created by the director's eye, something new in Tarantino's work). However, there are just too many set-pieces, as if the temptation to show-off could not be resisted. Jamie Foxx is persuasive as the ex-slave turned bounty hunter but Christoph Waltz very nearly steals most of their scenes together with his witty German bounty-hunter.  Leonardo DiCaprio is weird as the plantation owner into slave-fighting, almost transcending his usual self, whereas Samuel L. Jackson as the sycophantic head slave proves unable to do that even under old man makeup.  A film in line with Inglourious Basterds in many ways and showing Tarantino's development on many fronts but always with his glee in teasing the audience with anachronistic music (Jim Croce, modern rap), comic asides (the KKK-bag scene), cameos and recycled stars of the past (Franco Nero, Don Johnson), and so on.  Despite his greater control, he just can't control himself.  Finally, does the film tell us anything about slavery that we didn't already know? It is grim material for a film.

I watched Django Unchained by myself, which is a thing I've started doing now that I'm taking my reviews a little more seriously. It's a little degrading but totally worth it, now that I'm realising I just had the misfortune of watching bad movies when I went alone before, and it can actually be enjoyable, so long as the film itself is good.

Django Unchained is totally good.

It's not without flaws. It's broken up into pieces in much the same way as Tarantino's last effort, Inglourious Basterds, but where in that case the segments made up little chapters, in Django, the segments just unpleasantly breaks the story-flow apart and brings you out of the environment Tarantino worked so hard to create (also titling one of these chapters with no capital 's' in 'Somewhere' pissed off the OCD Grammar Nazi within).

Also, why did the soundtrack feel the need to sing about everything that was happening? I was watching the movie as it unfolded, and the twangy voices in the background served solely to aggravate me and bring me further out of the actual drama. It's meant to be an exploitation film, not a Randy Newman concert.

There's a scene where KKK forerunners reenact the Lion King, which was just plain ridiculous, but they (complete with Jonah Hill) at least manage to make this humorous, unlike my other qualms with Django which make it just plain stupid.

For the most part though, the film's great. There wasn't much chance of it being anything else, Tarantino's a master who I've enjoyed since his very beginning (though an argument could probably be made for the failings of Death Proof). The flashbacks are brilliant, the colour scheme is some of the most fantastic work I've seen, there's great lines such as "I like the way you die, boy" to walk away with, and the shootouts (though admittedly 100% foreseeable) are some of the most enjoyable work I've been able to watch this year.

People will complain about the film for many reasons, I'm sure. Not least amongst them is the fact that Django Unchained has use of the word "Nigger" probably more than any other film I've ever seen. But also because the pace wasn't fast enough for some, or maybe the events weren't all together historically accurate. But this film is powerful, and at the end of the day, Tarantino is here to right characters. Perhaps none in this were as staying as Hans Landa (portrayed by Austrian actor Christoph Waltz [Epic, Carnage, The Three Musketeers, The Green Hornet] who in Django plays Dr. King Schultz) of Inglourious Basterds, but the fact is he wrote a role for Leonardo DiCaprio (Inception, Gangs of New York, The Man in the Iron Mask, Critters 3, The Departed) that actually made me like him. Which is something I've been managing to avoid for years.

Samuel L. Jackson's (The Avengers, Captain America, Thor, Iron Man, Iron Man 2, The Spirit, 1408, S.W.A.T., Jackie Brown, Pulp Fiction) work in this alone is enough to make Django worth watching, not to mention the fact that Tarantino had me genuinely convinced that Jamie Foxx (Due Date, Law Abiding Citizen, Jarhead, Stealth) being up on a horse was a big deal, just because he's black. He cameos the (quite literally) most convincing Australian accent I've ever heard in my entire life (from a non-Australian, of course) and more importantly he does it by the side of genuine Aussie John Jaratt (Rogue, Wolf Creek). It may have had nearly as many endings as The Return of the King but Django Unchained is well worth the three hours it runs for.

Django Unchained, the latest in director Quentin Tarantino's string of gratuitously violent revenge flicks, is also the first film of his that I've had the opportunity to see in its entirety. I have no real grounding comparing it to his other films, so I want to see how it holds up compared to movies in general that deal with racism, or the Wild West. In the latter regard, Django Unchained was fantastic as a standalone action film. Right as I saw the opening scene, with Dr. King Schultz casually shooting a slaver dead in order to acquire Django, I was riveted to my seat. Despite the nearly three-hour length, I noticed no issues with pacing, and was continually invested in all the witty banter Tarantino had to offer. The writing, which won an Oscar, held the movie together, seamlessly combining comedy, drama, and general awesomeness into a tale of epic proportions. Django Unchained, first and foremost, is a character piece-nothing happens unless it reveals or alters a major character arc, and that gets rid of any banal repetition the movie would otherwise have to bear. Furthermore, the characters are unpredictable, making the jigsaw puzzle of their collective saga all the more interesting to solve. 

Any film can attempt to tackle the heavy subject of race, but it takes a masterpiece to flip the issue over its head with any real success. Django Unchained achieves this by reversing the roles of white and black, master and slave, and then makes this transition as natural as possible. For instance, plantation owner Calvin Candie is not only entirely dependent on his slaves for his profits and lifestyle but also entirely trustful of them with these things. Part of this humanization of the villains may stem from the good reputations of the A-list actors who play them, but the villains themselves are also written as what amounts to the living embodiments of hypocrisy. 

While the villains of this movie have muddled motivations, Django's own intent is obvious-to rescue his wife Broomhilda from slavery. Despite this being the first Tarantino film I've seen, I was well aware of Tarantino's penchant for over-the-top blood and gore, which made me worry that Django would trade his sense of heroism for pure revenge. Then I actually saw the movie rather than jumping to conclusions, and it seems that to Django, revenge IS heroism. Quite simply, the former slave has nothing left to lose, and must regain not only his wife but his dignity. Therefore, he'll never be morally satisfied until all who oppressed him feel the same wrath that was inflicted on him, on Broomhilda, and on all slaves. In this film, this path is the only one that makes any sense. 

This bloody, unapologetic variety of thematic expos√© also left me caught off-guard by the level of visceral comedy inherent in the film. All the humorous banter both veiled to the characters and made clear to the audience a growing ascent towards an epic showdown, a dramatic foil of every character onto one another: Django and Schultz, Schultz and Candie, Candie and his favorite slave Stephen, and Stephen and Django. Each case wrought mutual resentment out of the fundamentally polar and irreconcilable differences everyone holds between each other. Skin color is the easiest example, but the same applies for two people born into the same race-for instance, Schultz's intellect and sophistication inversely reflects Candie's feigned interest in the arts and cultures. Meanwhile, the title character of Django, whose hatred of those who enslaved him and others compounds with the visceral imagery of hotboxes, whiplashes, and runaway brands, never had much humor stem from his own character arc, instead working off of others' interpretations of him (i.e. paraphrasing his former owner with the line "I like the way you die, boy"). In this way, his life as a free man is shaped fully by his experiences in the movie. And just when matters settle down, BANG! Someone is lying, dead on the ground. Yes, there's a bit of blood, but I can easily tell it's fake. I was made to laugh at the demise of minor troublemakers or major outlaws, knowing that each of their actions in life were all in vain. I enjoyed myself despite my moral objections to murder, and I wanted more of the satisfying resolutions to petty characters. Anyone versed in these sorts of hard-R films may think I'm too na√Øve for my own good, while those who tend to avoid the films for these reasons might also try to reason some sense around me. This is the nature of the Tarantino film, and it will never go away. And I love it. 

So to sum matters up: the directing is superb, the writing is fantastic, and the acting is phenomenal. The movie knows how to make me laugh even and especially when drenched with the gratuity of Hollywood splendor. It parodies itself in its overdose of violence, In any case, I appreciate how this film retains all its viscosity and balances the violence with the right characters and plot needed to provoke that violence. No, it's not perfect, but that's not the point; the point is to have fun. Django has truly been unchained. And now, I feel the same way.

Django Unchained is not an excellent movie and certainly isn't Tarantino's best movie, but it IS a good movie overall (even despite the approx. 3hr runtime).  It shows how Tarantino has matured as a filmmaker over the past 20 years.  Previously rough edges are now smooth, familiar.  This includes the cheeky violence Tarantino is famous for.  His movies are the rare sort where it's legitimately okay to laugh at the sight of a woman flying full-force off screen while being gunned down in cold blood.  While Tarantino the screenwriter and filmmaker has reached a new level of maturity, Django breaks no real ground as far as storytelling goes, and breaking ground is what made Tarantino famous.  But I think Tarantino's most significant achievement with Django, thanks to Jamie Foxx's & Christoph Waltz's superb talents, is to create a new legend of the Old West (or more accurately, the Old South).  A new American myth as iconic as the real historical figures or any of Clint Eastwood's characters.  A film this memorable, an instant piece of our American culture, is a rare feat, and Django Unchained is worthy of that status.  Jamie Foxx, of course, deserves a great chunk of the credit for for bringing Django to life with the intensity that has shaped him into an Oscar-worthy actor.  But underneath that brooding, vengeance-filled intensity is a thin veneer of humor to remind us of Django's humanity.  I like his story, including the aspect of a person able to snatch Opportunity from adversity - the rare kind of opportunity which lets one discover who they were always meant to be.  Speaking of opportunity, I also enjoyed the opportunity for Leo DiCaprio to really cut loose in a role like he did with Calvin Candie.  Playing villains allows one to fully tap and explore a wild side.  Most protagonists have to restrain parts of themselves, and these are roles DiCaprio mostly portrays.  He's played angry & intense characters,  but none have quite let him unleash an erratic and amoral personality quite like Candie.  Christoph Waltz, I believe, was truly the best actor in this film, which is saying a lot considering his co-stars' performances.  But I loved his smooth-talking, intellectual character with an innate sense of justice that may or may not conflict with the laws and social mores of the country in which he operates.  Kerry Washington's performance was also solid, as was Samuel Jackson.  Like DiCaprio, he so rarely plays villains, especially calculating sniveling characters like Stephen.  I delighted in watching him pull that off spectacularly.  But Stephen is where the crux of my criticism lies.  Django Unchained is obviously a Magnum Opus for Tarantino, an epic to rival that of the Kill Bill movies while paying homage to spaghetti westerns of yore.  But even at almost 3 hours, you can feel Tarantino had to cut much of the story he intended to tell.  I wish he had found a way to split Django into a series of films because, again even at nearly 3 hours, this felt rushed.  I felt like some of the characters' stories were incomplete or discarded.  (I still maintain my theory that Stephen was the real power behind the Candyland throne and Calvin was just a front.  I really believe Tarantino intended this, but switched it to the current version for time or whatever).  You could argue the incomplete characters are hints at a much larger world of which Django and his adventures are a small part, adding another complex layer to this film.  I'd say that's a good argument, but it still doesn't shake the feeling that some of the storytelling art was cut for the sake of time.  That brings us full circle to why Django Unchained is such a good movie.  Even after nearly 3 hours, it imprints itself on our memories, leaving us wanting more, hoping to see or read more about Django and his world.

With a straightforward linear plot, a focus on one sole character, few flashbacks and a more restrained directorial style, Tarantino's eighth film is almost unrecognisable from the auteur's previous offerings (especially his latest output) but all the better in my eyes for it. Stylistically taking off where Inglorious Basterds left us (OTT historical fiction) Tarantino exclusively follows Jamie Foxx's Django from his break for freedom with Dr. King Schultz (played brilliantly by Christoph Waltz) through to his bounty hunter training and subsequent attempts to free his slave wife from the clutches of Calvin Candie. DiCaprio's Deep South slave plantation owner is another highlight in a film of great performances including Samuel L. Jackson's phenomenal turn as Stephen, Candie's entrusted and apologetic aging black slave. The acting is clearly top notch throughout and Tarantino's controlled direction and blinding score makes the (rather lengthy) 2 hours 40 minutes run-time a joy trather than a pain. With the amazing soundtrack accentuating the emotional journey, Tarantino has made a brilliant film and in this reviewer's eyes, the best since Pulp Fiction. Django does Entertain! Easily the best of the Best Picture noms last year (I'm looking at you, Argo), Django Unchained is a wonderful instance of Quentin Tarantino's ability to make films that look and feel like movies. What appears on the surface to be a cheesy, violent spaghetti western goes a ton deeper, touching on the themes of slavery, racism, and religion in real and often hilarious ways. Jamie Foxx, Leonardo DiCaprio, and Christoph Waltz all give Oscar-worthy showings (congrats to Waltz on actually winning one). I admit to rooting for Moonrise Kingdom for Best Original Screenplay, but I'm not too mad that it went to Tarantino.

My second Tarantino film that I've watched, which has been one of few Western films that I truly admire and re-watch more than once. I know there has been criticism towards the racism presented in this film, however the film is set during the slavery years, so it has contextual justification. Once again there is a superb cast, from the dynamic Jamie Foxx as the lead, from the sophisticated Leonardo DiCaprio and wise cracking Samuel L. Jackson. Once again, Christoph Waltz is the true highlight  as he becomes the charismatic, witty and law bringing bounty hunter. With a faster pace and bloodier action than his previous work, Django Unchained is likely to keep almost anyone entertained from start to end. Congratulations to Quentin Tarantino and Christoph Waltz on both winning their second Academy Awards of Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor.

Django Unchained is Tarantino's second historical project in a row. Although less urgent than his earlier work it is every bit as amoral and is not afraid to turn conventional movie mores on their head, in that a German is now one of the good guys. The story that unfolds lays bare the iniquities of U.S. slavery without recourse to indignity or maudlin sentiment. Indeed, it is the director's insistence that the audience make up their own minds on emotive issues such as this has always been a refreshing departure from the Hollywood mainstream. One niggle though, the great man appears in his customary cameo alongside two others, all sporting distinctly Australian accents. Now what three diggers are doing in the back-end of Mississippi in the mid 19th century is beyond me. But then, this is Tarantino and therefore he is forgiven all nit-picking.

This is absolutely an amazing movie. Cristoph Waltz's performance was the best I've seen of any actor in a while and brings into question what qualifies as "actor in a leading role" because of immaculate screen time. But regardless this is a fun movie, very well capturing the hate and violence of many white men against slaves around the time of the Civil War. Though Foxx does well as Django, the character is simply a bit uninteresting and stoic, though indeed likeable. Leonardo DiCaprio nails his egotistical Deep South slave owner Calvin Candy perfectly, once again leading people to question why this man is Oscarless at this point in time. Samuel L. Jackson shines in his role as a grumpy foulmouthed house slave on good terms with his master Candy. Though some question the gratuitiveness of the violence in the film, its well-done and well deserving of its Oscars.

"Django Unchained   " is a listless bore.Save a couple of genuinely funny bits,this movie continues Tarantino's delusion that his style of hasty cross referencing film genres regardless of kind of film he is attempting to make is revitalizing,hip and slick.This sloppy, pace-less,talky attempt at ironic effect.QT is a one trick pony.You can not even say that he has a style;what he does seem more a grab bag of shticks sewn together like Frankenstein's monster.In this case,what is on the table remains a dead heap .It's no good to blame the messenger for QT's latest venture in cinematic tedium. I wanted to like the film very much and kept waiting for some convincing, if stylized storytelling . The principle fault was pacing, which was pokey and slack. Genius though his dialogue may appear on the page, or the computer screen, Tarantino doesn't seem to have learned that film dialogue, even the conversation we consider "literate" or "bright", requires a ruthless efficiency.

The constant references to the cheesy tics and tacky tropes of old exploitation movies in the work of Tarantino as passed the point of being homages, tributes displayed in new films that, in themselves, are legitimate extensions of durable genre. Cringe as he might, Tarantino has created his own kind of formalism, a post-modern template in which the borrowing of elements from other films is no longer a clever, brilliant and innovative method of transgressing boundaries and revealing but has rather become what seems a knee-jerk response to a challenge to make a certain kind of movie. I agree with the assertion that there is a certain clubhouse knowingness about his films that distance the typical viewer from enjoying his films; the genius of genres is that the true masterpieces in Western movies, war movies, crime dramas, et al, is that they go well beyond the expectations of hard core fans and appeal to a greater audience that recognizes something greater than the mere satisfaction of genre expectations. To coin a phrase, the cliquishness is a buzz-kill and is, I think, more than cynical in attitude. All this mix and matching , bric-a-brac, and pastiche mongering assumes, by design, that surprise is no longer possible with film narrative and that what film makers need to be are little kids taking a hammer to the toys they are bored with. That is not my idea of a fun date.

 The characters here, especially those played by Christoph Waltz and Leonardo diCaprio, chatted up considerable dust storms of hyperbolization that would the dialogue equivalent of a jazz soloist improvising for too long .This is at the sacrifice of momentum, a quality that isn't achieved in "Django Unchained"- try as I might to suspend my disbelief, I was never convinced that the inevitable reckoning would result in the catharsis that even a hipster variation of a Jacobean revenge tragedy requires as a matter of form. Humanity and all its layered awfulness--lust, greed, avarice, revenge, slavery, racism, all those rotten instincts that create tension within individual characters who try to abide by codes of honor, decency and respect who then are transformed into somethng much uglier and wrathful--are summarily smothered by Tarantino's heavy hand and instead used as premise-giving props as the writer/director hits all the generic marks. In doing so, QT seems like a less than agile man learning how to dance, following the shoe prints laid out on the floor, "...one, two THREE, one, two THREE..."

Django Unchained, Quentin Tarantino's latest audacious picture, dealt boldly with a topic rarely explored in film. I appreciated how heavy subject matter was moulded into an incredibly entertaining piece of cinema, undoubtedly condemning the atrocities of the era, whilst avoiding simplistic moralising. Shocking juxtaposition of cruelty and comedy, frequently within scenes, created a particularly effective mood whiplash. True to form, much style is drawn from the director's love of homage; this time from the Spaghetti Western, he brings the visual intensity of stunning landscapes, and a memorable soundtrack, whilst indulging in the exquisite interiors and costumes of the period.

Masterful.

Set in the American South, only two years before the Civil War, Django (Jamie Foxx), a recently freed slave, sets out on a journey to find and free his wife (Kerry Washington) and take revenge on the cruel plantation owners, along with the help of bounty hunter Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz).

Tarantino deals with this story so simply that as his heroes have suffered such historic injustice, their revenge can never be too bloody or cruel, allowing for this to be a classic QT picture. Tarantino's natural instinct in film-making seems to be to exaggerate, and Django Unchained is no different. His use of blood is hysterical, creating a volcanic type eruption whenever a bullet strikes its target. Furthermore,Tarantino uses the N-word as often as he believes he can get away with, yet, I don't feel he over-stepped the mark. Tarantino films must always be watched knowing that what you are about to see is not trying to be a true depiction of the era or subject involved. It is simply Tarantino's take on the subject, and nearly always poking fun. Take Kill Bill for example, the action sequences are ridiculously unrealistic, with QT clearly making a joke about martial arts films. I feel something similar is happening with Django Unchained, as Tarantino writes his own history.

The film opens to a pair of brutish slave-traders who are dragging a chain-gang of black men across Texas. Next enters Dr King Schultz, a stylish German-born bounty hunter. Schultz dispatches the slave-traders in a superbly calm and comical style, and off he and Django, released from the chain-gang, go together. When Django explains he is looking for his German Speaking wife, Broomhilda, Schultz becomes entranced and agrees to help find and free Broomhilda, who happens to be under the ownership of plantation owner Calvin Candie (Leonardo DiCaprio).

Christoph Waltz follows up his excellence in Inglourious Basterds by delivering another phenomenal supporting performance, and a deserving winner of the Golden Globe. However, the stand-out performance was that of veteran Tarantino favourite Samuel L. Jackson, as Stephen, the housekeeper of Calvin Candie, and the most evil Uncle Tom. "Who dis nigger up on dat nag," is the reaction of Stephen seeing a free black man, and also the audiences introduction to Samuel L. Jackson. From his introduction onwards, Samuel L. captures every scene with his quick-wit, contagious laugh, and dark betrayal of Broomhilda. The character of Stephen perfectly highlights Tarantino's ability as a screenwriter, as the large portions of dialogue, mixed with the outbursts of violence, manage to successfully captivate the viewer.

Tarantino's best film since Pulp Fiction, one that should definitely not be missed.

J.Henderson.

Well, wasn't exactly what I expected. All I knew going in was it was up for a lot of awards and was about slavery. First off, I was not expecting the unbelievable gore. Sorry, when you shoot somebody, it does not look like that (hint: it looked like they were exploding, not being shot). Besides the gore, there were some unbelievable characters. Dr. Schultz was one of those 'I-can't-believe-he-just-did-that' characters that you, despite yourself, start to really like throughout, despite his kind of warped, almost psychopathic sense of humor. Jamie Foxx did good throughout, of course, playing first the unwitting accomplice to this mad dentist and turns into an emotionless, vengeful killer. DiCaprio for once played a character you HAD to hate, really going against his pretty-boy image, which was hard for most of us who watched to adjust to. And then there's Samuel L....what the heck! Came off as a bratty little butler who had his master by the coat-tails, which would not have happened. He was smarter than his own good. Not a stand out performance for him; it didn't work. The story line was well thought out, though very, very gruesome, portrayed the time they lived. Seemed very drawn out, though, and a lot of the fluff could have been cut (the long survey of DiCaprio's land, for instance). Overall, a good movie, but not everybody's cup of tea

If you want an exercise in over-acting, look no further than this film. The time for slapstick-levels of blood and carnage is over, Quentin. Time to remember how to tell a story, first, and lay on the cartoon aspects second. Remember Reservoir Dogs? Pulp Fiction? These movies told a story, first, and then used violence to help tell it. When Bruce Willis has to decide between sword or chainsaw, he doesn't do it out of a need to showcase hysterical violence, but rather to show a quick smirk at the audience before getting back to the story. This movie is all smirk, all the time.

Django Unchained, Quinton Tarantino Unleashed:

	Set in 1858, the last 2 years of the antebellum era, we see the Django played by Jamie Foxx marching in a slave chain gang when Dr. King Schultz, a bounty hunter liberates him in a most hilarious way. That is, by killing one of the slave traders and injuring another. When describing these actions, it shouldn't be funny by any standards yet, the genius and style of Quinton Tarantino makes it so. Quinton himself went on the other side of the camera to give us a brief but very explosive performance. I'm belly laughing at people getting shot, maimed, and blown up as if I was watching Looney Tunes. But there's plenty of drama and character development to enjoy as well. We see Django transforming from a timid slave into the confident bounty hunter sidekick to Dr. Schultz played by Christoph Waltz. And we see Dr. Schultz haunted by the atrocities of the antebellum era. 

I really enjoyed seeing Christoph Waltz playing the polar opposite of his SS character in QT's 2009 Inglorious Basterds, while maintaining his Austrian accent. Equally as delightful was Don Johnson who rejoined the QT team (see Machete 2010). Hopefully we'll see him as well as others to be regulars in Mr. Tarantino's movies. Leonardo DiCaprio is brilliant as the Slave owner/Mandingo fighting promoter and with the introduction of his character, Calvin Candie; the brutality escalates exponentially and with historic accuracy. But still Quinton's movie style goes from a horrific brutal scene to a humorous moment at light speed. In fact at one point I unintentionally drew attention to myself as I laughed just a little longer and a little louder than the rest of the audience at the cartoon like demise of a slave mistress. I won't give "another" spoiler by describing the scene exactly, but I thought it was one the hilarious moments as only Quinton can do with this subject matter.  

Django is further evidence of genius arising from humble beginnings. Not bad for a boy who started as a video store clerk. I'm just glad I was one of the polite customers who always rewound.

Actually thought this was one of Tarantino's weakest films.  Not as complicated or intriguing as his other work, and Django was hard to relate to. Not to mention zero strong female characters. Quite dissapointing.

I honestly can't say anything about Django Unchained. Being a film by Quentin Tarantino, it is indeed one of his VERY best films. This films centers around ex-slave-turned Bounty Hunter, Django Freeman and his mission is to find and rescue his estranged wife from Calvin Candie, a slaving owning business man of his own worth. With the help of Dr. King Schultz, he might as well be the "fastest hands in the south." I was downright pleased with the love and admiration that went into making this film. Not a single moment, was I ever bored at all. The time and setting was WELL respected. The action bits were well choreographed. The pacing was well timed and it didn't feel like it wasn't dragging at all. Tarantino is really famous for putting tremendous amount of character development and dialogue in his films and it clearly makes a great return in Django Unchained. The performances were stellar with Jamie Foxx as Django being all badass, Leo DiCaprio being a great Southern %$$hole (hence the time and setting), Sam Jackson just being awesome. Yet, out of all of the performances, Christopher Waltz was probably the most thrill seeking. His expressions, his dialogue, and his motives tells us that he is in no position to mess around. When he wants a job done.....he gets the job done. Hell, his beard looks like he wants to kill someone. The soundtrack is well placed and doesn't feel like it was just there for the sake of being there. The music gave us that classic Western flare that films like any of the Clint Eastwood Westerns. Hell, Western composing master, Ennio Morricone provides the score in it and it doesn't disappoint. So, I have said enough about Django Unchained and I advice you to go and see it. In fact, I am actually going to see it again BECAUSE of how good it is.

This journey leads them straight to Calvin Candie, played by Leonardo DeCaprio, and his Mississippi plantation. Here they find Broomhilda Von Shaft played by Kerry Washington who is Django's long lost love. This film is filled with several other stars including Samuel L. 82% (reduced from an 84%) Finally seen the famous Django Unchained by the almighty Quentin Tarantino, and I have to say, this is one of the most overrated films of 2012.  However, it is one of the few Tarantino films I have thoroughly enjoyed.  It reminds us of the horrors of the slavery era (though done many times already), and of course, adds the usual Tarantino twist to it, and the usual sly dialogue (Jonah Hill scene was the best imo).  But I will say that Django Unchained, albeit being a straightforward man reclaims his wife story, is still very well made and well acted, I overall enjoyed it.  DiCaprio should have been nominated, Jamie Foxx was decent, Christoph Waltz was superb as always, and L. Jackson has never been better.

If you didn't like Tarantino's variation on WWII in Inglorious Basterds you are not going to like this film. The film has nothing to do with Sergio Corbucci's 1966 Spaghetti Western Django apart from Jamie Foxx's character sharing the same name as Franco Nero's character in Corbucci's film. Franco Nero even shows up for an appearance as do a number of other familiar actors that were cast in the film. Tarantino is inspired by the Spaghetti Western genre (some original material for the score was composed by Ennio Morricone) and Blaxploitation films, particularly films like Mandingo(1976) set in the antebellum American South. Just as Tarantino thought that Hitler and his ilk got off too easy in WWII and turned Inglorious Basterds into a revisionist revenge fantasy, he thinks the Nabobs and their ilk in old South got off too easy and constructed another revisionist revenge fantasy here. I have no problem with that. I have never been a big fan of Jamie Foxx but he is good here, playing a gunslinger who like all good Spaghetti Western heroes is better and far cooler than his opposition. Still, its Christopher Waltz playing Django's benefactor, partner in bounty hunting, and friend who gets all the best lines and won an academy award for Best Supporting Actor. Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L. Jackson, and even Don Johnson are having a ball playing bad guys in this film. Tarantino's script gives them all terrific lines. But the best moment for me was when the great Franco Nero meets Jamie Foxx in a saloon. He asks him his name and Foxx replies, spelling out the name and explaining that the "D" is silent. In a classic "Fourth Wall" moment Nero replies "I Know."
